Gentlemen.- Your File 20 I.A.-Sask.

This is in reply to your letter of April 26th, enquiring as to the possibility of supplying the St. Alban's Indian Residential School with 400 yards of wire fencing, now situated at the M. & C. Aviation Company of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

Up to date of writing, this particular material has not been declared surplus to the Corporation, and until this is done we would not be able to deal with you in the matter. However, in any case, after the material has been declared we would not be in a position to make this fencing available to the School without cost, as our instructions from the Federal Government are that this organization must be a "one price Organization", irrespective as to whom the material is sold.

If the St. Alban's Indian Residential School would be interested in purchasing this fencing as and when it is declared surplus to the Corporation, and at the price which will be set by the Corporation, which will be in accordance with the market, we shall be very glad to deal with them in the matter, and to extend to them the same priority as is given to Municipalities, but we cannot, in accordance with our instructions, make any concessions in price.

If the above is of any interest, we shall be glad to hear further from you, at your earliest convenience, regarding this matter.

Yours very truly,
WAR ASSETS CORPORATION,
(sgd) P.B. Buckley,
Chief, Priority Control Section.

Dear Sir:

I wish to submit an offer of One Hundred ($100.00) Dollars for this. If accepted, kindly wire me reply collect.

On this we do not know just what we are getting. A few things needed are - spray nozzle, fuel line, oil lubricator, thermometer, fuel pump, injection pump, all governor springs, 2 main bearings, air intake valve, water pump, oil and grease fittings, 2 head gaskets injection push rods, and we do not know what the inside is like.

Re generator - no name plate - 7KW with pulley.

We would offer one hundred and ten ($110.00) for this.

Re water system Robinson Myers 391554, Motor H 62776.

Thompson Bros.

Per B.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith letter received from Thompson Brothers Garage, Spiritwood, Saskatchewan, making an offer of $100.00 for the engine, $110.00 for the Generator, and $25.00 for the motor for the water pump of the Onion Lake Church of England Residential School destroyed by fire.

The articles in question were salvaged and examined by Mr. Mitchell of the Surveys and Engineering Branch who, I understand, placed a valuation upon them. I do not know what valuation Mr. Mitchell gave and I am therefore not making any recommendation as to the advisability of selling at the prices offered.

It would appear to me that it might be advisable to have Indian Agent Cameron make enquiries in the district to ascertain whether or not there are others who might wish to quote on the equipment in question.

I have a copy of Mr. Christianson's letter, file No. 309-11 AGE., dated April 17th, 1944, in which he states he was attaching a list of the equipment salvaged from that school. There is no copy of the list on file here and I do not know its contents. When at the Onion Lake Agency recently I discussed this with Mr. Cameron and he informed me that a list had been sent Mr. Christianson. I was not aware at that time that there was not a copy of this kept on file at this office. I later called on Thompson Brothers of Spiritwood and the visit of Mr. Thompson to the Onion Lake Reserve to examine the equipment and make an offer was on my suggestion.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, August 31, 1945.

Memorandum: Indian Affairs Branch.

I acknowledge the receipt of your memorandum of August 31st, respecting the offer received from the Thompson Bros. Garage, Spiritwood, Saskatchewan, on three articles of salvage held at the Onion Lake Church of England Indian Residential School.

It was assumed that this equipment might be reconditioned, but apparently this could not be accomplished without considerable expense, particularly in respect to transportation costs. It has, therefore, been decided to accept the offer made by the Thompson Bros. Garage, as per their letter of August 24th last, as follows:

1. Fairbanks-Morse Engine, 25 H.P., Style 'H', No. C.27732..................$100.00

2. Generator (no name plate), 7KW, with pulley..........................110.00

3. Water Pump System, Robinson Myers, No. 391554, Motor H-62776.............25.00

Due to the remote district in which this equipment is located, and the fact that there are no other bidders, the Principal of the School might be instructed to dispose of the above salvaged articles and have the cheque made out in favour of the War Assets Corporation, Montreal, Quebec. Please forward the cheque to this office, together with complete information regarding the sale, and also a full description of the articles disposed of. The matter will then be reported to the War Assets Corporation and the cheque forwarded in settlement, in order to close out the transaction.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

May I herewith forward the following suggestion that the sum of $450.00 be allocated to the school to be used for the purpose of renovating the interior of the building.

This work is to be undertaken as a vocational project and the painting to be undertaken by the senior male pupils during the winter months under the guidance of an experienced instructor. Your sincere consideration in this matter would be appreciated, as the senior pupils need to be fully occupied apart from their academic studies in the class room.

It would also be appreciated if this matter could be considered as most urgent.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal
(Rev. Henry Ellis)
Ottawa, November 16, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to interior painting at the St. Alban's School.

I do not understand from your letter if the amount of $450.00 is required for material alone or if this includes labour as well. In either case the cost of the materials will be more than $50.00 and consequently, as you are aware, the order will have to be placed through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. Please let me know the quantity and colour of the paint which you consider is needed.

I trust that the employment of senior pupils to do the work will not bring criticism from the parents. From your letter it might be inferred that the senior pupils would be fully occupied with this work, apart from the time of their academic studies in the classroom. I hardly think that you really mean this.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend Henry Ellis,
Principal,
St. Alban's Indian Residential School,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Sirs,

I am an ex-service man discharged last spring from the army with the rank of sergeant with almost four years active service. I feel that I am having a fast one pulled on me, and this is the reason why I think so.

About two months ago Rev. Ellis, the Anglican Indian School in Prince Albert and I exchanged mangles with the understanding that he receive One hundred and thirty-five dollars ($135.00) less Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for my mangle and he would pay the freight on the school mangle to Melfort. Now he claims that I wasn't, but an even trade.

Common sense will tell you that it couldn't be when I paid One hundred dollars ($100.00) out of my gratuity money for my mangle and had sixty-one dollars ($61.00) worth of work done also to make an even trade or a mangle that is an old make in the first place and also not knowing what shape it is in it just isn't so.

So you see Sir it couldn't possibly have been an even trade on my part for I would not have made an even trade in the first place.

So let I would like a check for Sixty dollars and if that is not forthcoming to authorize Mr. Ellis at the Anglican school to return my mangle.
Please treat this as urgent. I would prefer to have my message back. Thank you.

Yours Truly,
Melfort, Saskatchewan

Attention of Col. Neary

In connection with a discussion we had the last time I was in Ottawa, accompanied by Mr. Ramage of the Public Works Department I visited the site of Ex-Army Camp 128, Basic Training Centre, Prince Albert, which is to be vacated shortly. Some of the buildings presently in use have been used temporarily and some are deteriorating fast as the result of abuses.

There is a man by the name of Eustace Kertin, a veteran of the First Great War and a pensioner, who is living in one of the buildings and has been giving them what care he is able to give them, besides looking after a good orchard and garden on the premises. It would appear to me that the first action which should be taken is to have all of the buildings turned over to the Department of Public Works and have Mr. Kertin appointed on a salary to take care of them. By this action they will receive no further damage and not be subjected to theft such as resulted at the R.C.A.F. Station at North Battleford between the time that the Department of National Health and Welfare considered taking some of them over for hospital purposes and the time that a man was actually appointed to take care of them.

There are many buildings which could be made suitable for school purposes as an annex to the St. Alban's Indian Residential School or as an Indian residential school separate from St. Alban's School, according to Departmental intent. Naturally it would be advisable to have a suitable location of buildings adjacent to each other and this can be more conveniently carried out if all of the buildings are under the Department of Public Works for redistribution.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Foran,

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant, your File IA-IA8-679G, I beg to say that I am advised by telephone that the names on the eligible list for the position Inspector of Construction, province of Saskatchewan, are as follows, in the order named:

Mr. A. Taillon,
Mr. Wm. J. Bayne, and
Mr. J. W. Ruttan.

We expect that we will be erecting another school in Saskatchewan, the tenders for which will be called at an early date, and, if so, we would like to employ Mr. Taillon for this work. Mr. Bayne did not prove satisfactory last year to the Indian Commissioner, and we would not care to re-employ him. I am advised that Mr. Ruttan has obtained another position. Such being the case, I think it would be well to advertise the position Inspector of Construction for the Onion Lake school, and I would ask that you take this action at the earliest possible date. I am inclosing requisition herewith.

If the weather is favourable to the work on the Onion Lake school being started and we require an Inspector before the result of the competition is known, I presume we might employ Mr. Taillon for this work for a few days.

Yours very truly,

Wm. Foran, Esq.,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Lang Turner, wife of our Indian Agent at Onion Lake, who informs me that her husband is far from well, and is to undergo a most critical operation within the next few days.

If Mr. Turner survives the operation it will be a long time before he is able to take up his active work again.

Mr. Turner was a hard-working man and most conscientious, and I fear from what I can gather that he should have attended to his ailment long before he did.

I will keep you advised if I hear anything further regarding his condition. He is at present in Victoria, B.C. with his wife. The Agency office is being run by his daughter, and the outside work by Farmer Booth.

The situation created by this unfortunate matter is going to make it most difficult for us in carrying out our building programme at that point during the coming summer. It seems to me that we should have a picked man to represent us on this job. I would not think of having a man of the type

According to law, preference is given among candidates possessing the necessary qualifications, first to persons who are in receipt of a pension on account of disabilities received as a result of war service, who by reason of such service are unable to continue their pre-war occupation, and who have not been successfully re-established, and secondly, to persons who have been on active service overseas or in the high seas.

Dear Colonel Neary:

My predecessor was very keen on providing motion picture projectors in all our schools and had managed to collect from various organizations and private funds a sufficient amount to meet about half the estimated requirements. He had hoped that the schools might raise the remaining half from some source or other but this has proved to be out of the question because few, if any, of our schools have any fund which they could devote to this, or any other, purpose.

In my view, motion picture projectors should be considered a valuable training aid and, in consequence, should be supplied by the Department in the same way as other educational requirements.

St. Alban's Residential School:

This school is attempting to care for 156 pupils plus a few wards of pre-school age. The only relief from the overcrowding is obtained by sending all boys but two to sleep in the former army barracks. Two little boys were being permitted to sleep in the junior girls' dormitory. They are very little boys, but I have pointed out the possibilities for exaggeration.

Even for the hundred girls who are housed (or rather "scraped up") in the building, the sleeping accommodation and the sanitary arrangements are a sorry spectacle. There are too few windows, and even these are filled with blocks to preclude their being opened wide.

Plumbing fixtures are too few in number, and are not well maintained.

The general effect is depressing to the inmates, both children and staff, as the cluttered state of things does not inspire them to keep things ship-shape. At 4 p.m. I found some girls still languidly sweeping up, even though the air was a little stale.

The bathrooms are not appropriate for an institution of this type. They contain the usual three pieces. The porcelain in nearly every case was "frowzy." I looked in vain for their house. The supervisor said they must have fixed up the nation"—obviously some time ago.

In the boys' toilets the seats have been removed although urinals are provided. They did, however, have toilet tissue in two of the three compartments.

The problem is to decide whether the Department or Bishop Martin should meet these repair costs of

When the lease was renewed, the following letter was sent to Bishop Martin on December 6, 1948:

"You will recall our recent discussion with regard to the renewal of the lease on the above building. In reviewing our files, I find that Mr. Roey wrote you as follows on December 23, 1943:

'I have noticed Your Lordship's reference to taxes, and the city levy appears to me to be very reasonable. Would it be acceptable to the Diocese if we spent a minimum of $2,000.00 on the school, in lieu of rent, for the year 1944, and allowed you the sum of $2,000.00 annually for the next 4 years, on the understanding that any repairs that might be necessary would be undertaken either by the Diocese or by the Principal and that the taxes also would be paid by the Diocese? If this allowance is acceptable to you, it might be advisable to submit a voucher for one half the amount semi-annually.'

"I understand that this lease was to run for the period of five calendar years and that it will expire on December 31, 1948.

"In view of increased costs of repairs and general rental rises, I would like to suggest that the amount of $2,500.00 a year be considered as the amount of the new lease on this building for the next five years. Dear Major MacKay:

Re: Onion Lake Residential School (St. Albans)

I must apologize for my delay in answering your letter of April 5th regarding the above school but I am sure you will realize that this is one of the busiest weeks of the year for me.

I was greatly surprised to read the contents of your letter and to learn that so much needed to be done to meet the requirements of the Provincial Fire Inspector, because before the school was opened my understanding was that the fire authorities were completely satisfied.

Nevertheless, there is nothing else we can do but agree to their requirements because I should not be happy to know that the school was not safe for the children to live in; and we must remove as far as possible every fire hazard from the building. I fully concur in your finding that this work should be carried out immediately. In this connection, I do wish Mr. Ostrander had kindly given me the opportunity of discussing this most important matter with him before forwarding to you his findings; because, as I say, I had no idea that such conditions existed.

Now with regard to the cost. Again there is nothing else we can do but carry out what is suggested by you in your letter, although I rather thought that the Department would like to come to our help, at least to some extent, to meet this very heavy cost. I wonder if you could see your way to help us in this regard? I have kept in fairly close touch with this school since the death of the Principal, Mr. Fisher, and I am fully convinced of the good work it is doing for our Indian children; and, of course, my great ambition for this building is that it be taken over by the Government and used for the providing of higher education to Indian boys and girls here in the West who show signs of being capable of absorbing such education. The building is admirably situated for this purpose in every regard; and I trust that in the not too distant future my hopes in connection with this school may be realized.

With Easter Greetings,

Sincerely yours,

Following the destruction of the Lac la Ronge Church of England Residential School by fire in December of 1945, the Department made arrangements to rent the above mentioned building which is owned by the Church of England Diocese of Saskatchewan, and which is located in the City of Prince Albert.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge your letter of June 17th with reference to the question of granting permission to the Indian Affairs Branch of your Department to dispose of a barn, garage, chimneys, etc., at the former Onion Lake C.E. Residential School, Sask., as agents for the Corporation.

Careful consideration has been given to this request but it does not seem desirable that War Assets Corporation should grant this permission unless in very exceptional circumstances and this particular case can hardly be considered to come within that category.

We have on one or two occasions granted permission to your Department to act as our agent for the sale of buildings, and as late as June 3rd I wrote to Mr. Pratt on this matter in respect to certain buildings at the Pasqua Indian Reserve, copy of my letter is attached for your ready reference. The factors which I mentioned in that letter would apply in a large measure to the present case and my answer must be the same.

However, we do desire to co-operate with your Department to the fullest extent possible in respect to the buildings at your Indian Reserves, and for this purpose the following procedure is suggested which would allow the sale to be conducted in a large measure under the supervision and advice of your Mr. Davis.

It is suggested that the following procedure be followed:-

1. Your Department should make a declaration in the ordinary way to War Assets Corporation of the property which is surplus and to be sold.
2. This Department of War Assets Corporation will process the declaration in the ordinary way and in this connection we can use Mr. Davis' report of May 31st as to the structure and condition of the buildings as the basis of our valuation.

3. We will issue tender notices to be posted according to our regular procedure in local post offices in the vicinity, and in addition we will supply Mr. Davis with a number of the tender notices which he can distribute to parties which he feels might be interested.

4. As a condition of the sale we will specify that all interested parties are to apply to Mr. Davis for permission to inspect the surplus properties offered for sale.

5. On receipt of the bids we will select the purchaser, secure his money and the necessary restoration deposit. We will then advise Mr. Davis of the successful bidder and send him the custodian copy of the sales order and the necessary handover certificate for signature by the purchaser. Mr. Davis can supervise delivery to the purchaser and return us the handover certificate. He could then satisfy himself that the property is removed and the restoration of site carried out in a manner satisfactory to him. In due course he can advise us and we will then be in a position to restore the restoration deposit to the purchaser.

It seems to me that this would be a satisfactory procedure for disposal of any Indian Reserve property and if it meets with your approval we will be glad to have the declaration in due course.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) J. D. Gardner,
Director, Lands & Buildings Department.

REPORT on the INSPECTION of the
CHURCH OF ENGLAND BOARDING SCHOOL, ONION LAKE.

From Jan. 1st, 1911, to March 31st, 1912.

Date of inspection, March 28th, 1912.

Staff.

1. The staff of the school at this date includes the following members:
   Rev. J. R. Matheson, as principal;
   Mrs. E. B. Matheson, M.D., medical attendant;
   Miss Smith, girls' matron;
   Miss Gladys Matheson, boys' matron;
   Joseph Chamberlin, teacher;
   Maria Money, cook.

The day of inspection was Joseph Chamberlin's last day as teacher, and on the following day his duties were assumed by Miss Gladys Matheson in addition to her work as boys' matron. This arrangement may, however, be only temporary.

Admissions and discharges.

2. The attendance register shows:

Enrolled Jan. 1st, 1911, 10
Admitted since, 6
Total, 16
Discharged 1

Enrolled March 31st, 1912, 15.

This enrolment includes 2 pupils who have been absent since Aug. 1st last and are not likely to return; the present actual attendance is therefore 13 pupils.
Non-treaty attendance.

3. In addition to the foregoing there are in attendance 18 non-treaty pupils, of whom 13 are boarders and 5 day pupils. These figures show about the average attendance of non-treaty children throughout the year.

Grading of pupils.

4. The pupils are graded in their school work as follows:

| Treaty pupils | Non-treaty pupils |
|---------------|------------------|
| Boys          | Girls            | Total | Boys | Girls | Total |
| St. I         | 6                | 3     | 9    | 5     | 5     | 10    |
| St. II        | 1                | 1     | 2    | 1     | 2     | 3     |
| St. III       | -                | -     | -    | 1     | 3     | 4     |
| St. IV        | -                | 1     | 1    | -     | 1     | 1     |
| St. V         | -                | 1     | 1    | -     | 1     | -     |
| Total         | 7                | 6     | 13   | 7     | 11    | 18    |

Progress in studies.

5. Fair progress has been made in reading, writing, number work, geography and language. The progress of the senior classes is more decided than that of the beginners, with whom the methods employed by the teacher count for much. The general tone of the work is only fair; the pupils are moderately attentive and diligent; but there is no enthusiasm. Physical exercises of all kinds have latterly been neglected, but will be resumed at once under Miss Matheson's direction.

The pupils are tidy in their clothing and general appearance, and orderly in their conduct.

Teacher.

6. Joseph Chamberlin, who has had charge of the class-room for about eight months, is an ex-pupil of the Battleford industrial school. He has passed the teachers' non-professional third-class examination, but has had no normal training. He leaves now to continue his studies, and after passing the second-class examin-

ation he intends taking a course of normal training, after which he will probably return to his present position in this school. He is a cripple owing to an attack some ten years ago of infantile paralysis or something of that nature, and is able to move around only with crutches; but he is intellectually bright and is treated with due respect by the pupils.

Throughout the quarter ended June 30th last the class-work was conducted by Miss Armstrong, a temporary member of the staff, who was not a trained nor experienced teacher, and who appears to have had but little aptitude for the duties.

Miss Matheson, who now takes charge of the class-work, is merely returning to her former duties, after an interval of about a year spent in a course of hospital training. She has had no normal training; but her natural aptitude for her duties is exceptionally good; she has picked up some of the best methods with beginners; and she infuses considerable energy into the work of all the classes. I visited the class-room again on Apr. 2nd for the special purpose of observing her methods of conducting the work.

Class-room and equipment.

7. The class-room affords ample space, good lighting and good ventilation. It is a cold room, but adequate provision is made for heating in two large box stoves and a large supply of good fuel. There are two entrances to the room, one for the boys and one for the girls.

I have said above that the conduct of the pupils is good; but in the condition of the pupils' desks and a portion of the school material there are evidences of some rudeness among the pupils at some time during the past year. A few of the desks are damaged, and half a dozen new ones would be required; while the slates and

books give indications of careless handling. These are for the most part the property of the Principal, as are also more than half the desks.

Dormitories.

8. The dormitories afford sufficient air-space; and though there is no regular system of ventilation yet by the careful use of doors and windows a fairly pure atmosphere appears to be maintained. However, so far as the older building, or girls' residence, is concerned the condition in which the atmosphere is kept depends largely upon the effort and diligence of the staff; and I cannot say that this building, either as regards the dormitory or the building generally, complies with the Department's requirements. The boys' residence is constructed on a more modern plan and there are better facilities for ventilation.

Heating.

9. Neither building has stone or concrete foundation, nor any basement except a small vegetable cellar; and the buildings are heated throughout by wood stoves. Good, dry wood is liberally supplied, and the buildings are well heated.

Fire escapes.

10. The girls' buildings is but two storeys in height, and so well provided with means of exit that special fire escapes are quite unnecessary. The boys' building is of three storeys, all above the ground. The dormitory is in the third storey, and there is but one exit, namely, by a stairway situated in the middle of the building. A folding steel ladder was to have been provided some time ago, but it has not been done. However, the Principal assures me that such a fire escape will be installed without delay; and the Agent states that he will see to it that this matter is not neglected.
11. There is a small but suitable building, situated at a distance of about 100 yards from the residence buildings, which some years ago was fitted up for hospital purposes and has from time to time been utilized as such by Dr. Matheson in connection with her duties as medical attendant both to the school and to the reserve. It has been occupied in the case of infectious diseases among the pupils, and for both infectious and non-infectious diseases among the Indians of the reserve generally, and has served a good purpose at times.

Industrial training.

12. Though there is no formal instruction in any industry, yet there are adequate facilities for training in the usual range of industries by actual practice. The training of the girls is at present much better than that of the boys. Special attention has latterly been given to sewing and knitting; and on the whole the girls are receiving a useful training. As for the boys, they are rather too small for instruction in anything but a very limited range of agricultural industry; yet in the care of a few head of stock and in gardening they have sufficient practice. A sufficient number of cows and horses are kept, and a sufficient area of garden is worked, for the actual requirements of the school; and this work is done under the direction of an intelligent labouring man who is employed in connection with the school and mission, but who is not included in paragraph 1 above as a regular member of the staff.
13. Since my last inspection, or at least since April 1st last, no instruction has been given in hygiene, calisthenics, physical drill, or any of the subjects outlined in the latter part of Clause 9 of the Agreement which came into effect Apr. 1st, 1911. The teacher who now takes charge will, however, give instruction in at least some of these branches, and in all to the best of her ability. The Principal expresses it as his intention to live up to the spirit and intent of this agreement.

Respectfully submitted,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Onion Lake,

REPORT on the INSPECTION of the ONION LAKE
CHURCH OF ENGLAND BOARDING SCHOOL.

From April 1st, 1912, to March 31st, 1914.

Date of inspection, March 31st, 1914.

Staff.

1. The staff is composed of -
Rev. J. R. Matheson, as principal;
Dr. E. B. Matheson, matron and medical attendant;
Miss Rema Matheson, assistant matron;
Miss Leita Matheson, teacher;
Mrs. A. J. Hanson, house-keeper;
Miss Carrie Money, (pupil), cook.

Attendance.

2. The attendance is as follows:
Authorized attendance of Indian boarders, 18
Actual attendance (enrolment) " " 13
Present in classes at inspection, 11.

One pupil, Carrie Money, who is about 16 years of age, is constantly employed in the residence, giving very satisfactory service as cook; while one boy, Jeffrey Quinney, was absent without leave on the reserve, his father promising, however, to bring him back at once.

There are also in attendance 6 non-grant-earning boarders and 2 day pupils, 7 of whom were present at inspection.
Grading of pupils.

3. The pupils are graded in their classwork as follows:

| Standard | Boys | Girls | Total |
|----------|------|-------|-------|
| I        | 3    | 1     | 4     |
| II       | 1    | 1     | 2     |
| III      | 3    | -     | 3     |
| IV       | 2    | -     | 2     |
| V        | -    | 2     | 2     |
| Total    | 9    | 4     | 13    |

Examination of classes.

4. The examination, which included reading, dictation, language, numbers, geography, and written exercises on slates and paper, was generally satisfactory.

The pupils read intelligently, with some expression, and with a rather good pronunciation.

They write dictation with a fair degree of ease and accuracy, as their ears appear to be accustomed to the language from daily association in classes and at recreation with English speaking children.

They speak English with some freedom and confidence, and use it moderately well in written composition.

Number work is taught in a practical way, and good results are being attained.

The pupils of the fourth and fifth standards show a general and superficial acquaintance with the physical and general geography of the world, and a somewhat closer acquaintance with that of North America. Maps are constantly used.

Singing, hygiene and physical exercises have a place in the time-table; but in these the pupils were not examined on this occasion.
5. The teacher, Miss Leita Matheson, is but 18 years of age and has had no special training for her work. She has, however, fair scholarship and is unusually well adapted to the work of the school-room. She is alert and energetic, and has easy and complete control of her classes. A lively interest is created and well sustained. Her education was received in part at St. Alban's College, at Prince Albert, where well qualified teachers are always employed; and her methods, if largely suggested from her own experiences as a student, are rather well adapted and successfully employed.

6. The main buildings consist of a girls' residence and a boys' residence. The former includes the staff's quarters and the dining rooms, while the class-room is in the boys' building.

The girls' residence has been enlarged from an ordinary mission dwelling by frequent additions during the past twenty years, until it has come to cover considerable ground but is devoid of uniform plan or adaptation to its present use. It consists in part of two storeys and in part of one; it has no substantial foundation and only a partially excavated basement. It is heated by wood stoves, lighted by lamps, and is dependent mainly on the use of doors and windows for ventilation.

The boys' residence is of three storeys, was erected about eight years ago, and is in several respects a building better suited to its purpose than the one last described. It contains, on the ground floor, the common class-room, which is a
spacious, well lighted and well ventilated room.

A log building, which had for some time past been used as a store room, was destroyed by fire early in the spring.

There is a suitable and fairly well equipped hospital, standing at a distance of some 75 yards from the other buildings, which has at times served a good purpose for the isolation of pupils suffering from measles.

Accommodation and equipment.

7. For the present reduced attendance, or for the authorized attendance of 18 grant-earning pupils, the present buildings, so far as space and equipment are concerned, afford ample accommodation.

Fire protection.

8. The fire-fighting appliances on hand are inconsiderable; but there is some protection in the isolation of the buildings, the residences being about 60 yards apart. In case of fire the building in which it originated would in all probability be destroyed; but there is safe means of escape for all the occupants under any circumstances.

Class-room equipment.

9. The class-room is furnished with two large box stoves, suitably situated to heat the entire room with a fair degree of uniformity. It is furnished with a full supply of pupils' desks, a teacher's table, 2 chairs, stationery cupboard, and a small organ. There is a rather complete supply of maps, but some of them are in poor condition, being much the worse for use. The blackboard is of slated cloth, of sufficient dimensions, 80 sq. ft., and neatly mounted and
framed; but like slated cloth generally, it takes the chalk poorly and the writing is always indistinct and at times scarcely legible. In my opinion it should be replaced by a similar area of Hyloplate board, which could be inserted in the present frame and moulding.

Live stock.

10. The live stock includes 4 horses, 2 cows, 4 pigs, 30 hens and 6 turkeys. The Principal formerly kept a herd of cattle outside the reserve, from which he derived his beef supply; but these have recently been disposed of.

Garden produce.

11. No farming is done in connection with the school; but a fairly good garden is cultivated, producing a supply of roots and vegetables which is usually sufficient, as it proved during the past season.

The Principal's health.

12. Owing to advancing years and failing health Mr. Matheson is not by any means as energetic in the management of his affairs as he once was; and he appears to be anxious to be relieved of the care of the institution. In such a case it is doubtful whether another competent man could be found to undertake it; and it is possible, and would probably be best, that it should be continued as a day school.

Respectfully submitted,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

   In addition to these, 2 Treaty and 11 Non-treaty children have been attending as day pupils; thus the total attendance in classes was 36 at the time of inspection.

3. For class-work the pupils were graded as follows:

Teacher -

The teacher, Miss A. L. Cunningham, holds First Year Standing in Manitoba University. She has no special training for teaching but has had years experience, all in Indian Schools, namely Lac La Bonge, Cross Lake and Island Lake. Miss Cunningham displays great earnestness and enthusiasm in her work, has complete control of her classes, good methods of presenting work to pupils of all grades, and a view to the ultimate aim in connection with all the exercises of the school-room and all her duties.

Examination of Classes -

Satisfactory progress has been made in reading, dictation, writing, language and geography. The pupils have a good practical use of English, according to their different grades, and give evidence of a fair understanding of what they read. They read with some expression and a good pronunciation. They show a good elementary acquaintance with local and general geography. Their familiarity with numbers is practical and useful as far as it goes; but even in Standard IV it is limited to operations in the simple rules and with integers alone, or fractions of the simplest description. The pupils' writing shows steady improvement; but little attention has been given...
to drawing, owing to the fact that the Teacher's time is too fully occupied with other subjects.

Physical exercises and drills are practiced regularly, but hygiene has been taught only incidentally in connection with other lessons and with general routine.

A time-table is on hand, but the subjects are not all fully provided for. The Teacher's attention was called to this, which will be remedied.

It is a difficult matter to follow out a fixed order and apportionment of time when the subjects and the classes are so numerous. Miss Cunningham has evidently been making the best use of her time and that of the pupils; but it will be helpful at least to have all the subjects represented on the time-table and a due proportion of time allotted to them.

Class Room -

6. This is a spacious room affording ample floor-space and air-space; it is well lighted, well ventilated and is comfortably heated in any kind of weather with two large box stoves.

The class-room is well equipped with 20 double pupils' desks, teacher's table and chair, organ, stationary cupboard, 95 sq. ft. of Nylol-plate black board, a terrestrial globe and wall maps of the hemispheres, Canada, North America and Europe.

Main Building -

7. The main building is a frame structure 50' x 80', of 2 stories, and a small basement. For foundation the building rests on
mud-sills, the roof is of wood shingles, a balcony extends along 50 feet of the south side. The interior finish is of lumber and the building is painted, both the interior and exterior; but in many parts the building is in need of renewing. The building as it stands at present consists of a small original dwelling house, which has been enlarged to its present proportions by numerous additions.

Further alterations and additions are still being made and some improvements in the interior arrangements are also being effected; but there is still such a lack of unity in the interior plan that it cannot be said that the building is either convenient or in any respect well adapted to its present purpose. The one advantage is that for the present attendance at least, it has all necessary capacity and air-space.

This building contains:

- Quarters for the Principal and his family
- Pupils' Dining Room
- Staff's Dining Room
- Kitchen
- Girls' Dormitory
- Office
- Dispensary

Boys' Building - The Boys' building is also a frame structure 30' x 40', and of three stories. The foundation is of heavy sills resting on substantial blocks. It is covered with rubber roofing. There are two exterior entrances on the ground floor and one on the second floor. The inter-
for of the walls is finished with lumber and the ceilings with metal; and the building is painted throughout.

The building is generally in good repair, except that it is hard to heat, in consequence of the shrinking of the lumber in the walls.

It contains the following apartments:

Class-room.
Royal Dormitory.
Clothing Room.
Royal Recreation Room.

Like the Class-room, which is on the ground floor, the building is heated throughout by means of box stoves.

For lighting unusually good provision is made, by numerous windows in all apartments. The only artificial light in this building, as in the main building, is furnished by coal-oil lamps.

Though no complete system of ventilation is provided for, yet by the use of several devices, chiefly that of fan-lights over the windows, which is provided throughout the building, the air is readily changed and no serious difficulty is experienced in keeping it in a wholesome condition.

Hospital -

A separate building, at about 50 yards from either of the school buildings, has for some years been devoted to hospital purposes, either for the school or for the Indians on the Reserve. It has been used for isolation cases on several occasions.

It is a properly finished log building on foundation of blocks and covered with rubber roofing. It is well lighted, heated with stoves and maintained in a sanitary condition.
Farm & Garden -

10. Some two years ago, the Principal met with an accident whereby he was deprived of the sight of one eye and since that time the out-of-door industries have been more or less neglected; and indeed the general management of the institution has devolved mainly upon the other members of the staff.

The farm products of last season consisted of a small crop of green feed. No potatoes were grown and but few other roots and vegetables. Fortunately the school was able to purchase its supplies of these articles at reasonable prices.

Livestock -

11. The Livestock maintained in connection with this school includes the following:

- 6 Horses.
- 2 Cows.
- 15 Pigs.
- 30 Pigs.

The Principal has in addition a herd of cattle, which are kept at a distance and outside of the Reserve, and from which the school's beef supply is mainly derived.

Management -

12. Under present conditions the school is not being maintained within its revenue. If the attendance were larger this would be somewhat improved, and there are children in the vicinity who should be attending this school and who will probably be enrolled in the near future, as there are also a few on the Reserve at Onion Lake who should be attending the Roman Catholic School, but whose education thus far has been neglected.

Report on Inspection of Church of England Boarding School - Onion Lake, Sask.

Inspection was made on March 4, 1916.

Attendance.

The total enrolment of resident children is 29. There are also non-treaty children, mostly white, attending day school to the number of 14, making a total enrolment of 43. At time of inspection there were 34 pupils present, 6 were absent of whom 5 were sick with minor ailments and 3 were visiting friends.

Grading.

| IV    |      |       |       |

Conduct and Clothing.

The behaviour of pupils in school is very good and they are suitably and comfortably clothed.

Teacher.

Miss A. L. Cunningham had first years training in Manitoba University and has taught in Indian Schools for the last 5 years. She understands the temperament of the Indian child exceedingly well and is this way she is able to impart knowledge with a large degree of success. She is most enthusiastic and thorough in her work and has complete control over her pupils.

Examination of Classes.

A time schedule which includes all subjects taught is adhered to.

Reading - In Grades I and Junior II the forming of simple sentences was good.

In Grade II senior the reading was exceedingly well done.

Grade III was well advanced in reading and Grades IV and V read extracts in a very fine manner.

The fact of some white children being included in the classes has a marked effect upon the Indian children. They speak out well and their pronunciation is good. From the same cause there is less difference shown by the Indian pupils in the junior forms.

Writing - Samples were produced and copy books examined.
Onion Lake Boarding School.

and in most grades, especially in Grade IV the writing was exceedingly good.

Spelling - Junior Grade II were asked to spell the days of the week and months of the year which they did satisfactorily.

In grades III and IV quite severe tests were given and answered very well indeed.

Arithmetic - In all grades they show an intelligent knowledge of their work and especially so in the higher grades where the instruction takes them into decimals.

History - The "Story of the Canadian People" is being taught in higher grades and in grade III "The Great Men of Canada". They are also familiar with the facts of the present war. Questions were answered well and without any hesitation.

Geography - In Grades III and IV questions were put on the provinces, Capitale, Rivers, Railways, etc., of Canada and were very well answered.

Drawing - Samples of drawings of familiar objects were shown which were very good. In the higher grades map drawing is extra well done.

Hygiene - Elementary facts in Hygiene are taught in the lower grades and more advanced instruction is given in the higher grades. The teacher is taking up this work enthusiastically and giving it a prominent place in their studies.

Physical Exercises - In the summer, drill and exercises are given in the open. The pupils went through their exercises in a very able manner to organ accompaniments.

Class Room.

This room is of generous dimensions with large floor space. It has 9 large windows with 12 lights, which give ample light and ventilation. It is heated by box stoves which are in good condition and the stove pipes securely fixed.

The class room is well equipped with desks, accommodation consisting of 13 double desks and several rough made desks. The latter, however, are being replaced by desks which were under order at the time of inspection. The general equipment is good, has ample blackboard and maps.

Buildings

The main building is rather old and not in very good repair. The interior in many places needs repainting and, as it is at present, is anything but attractive. There have been no improvements during the past year.

Ample air space is provided in the various rooms. The girls' dormitory while kept in clean condition is not at all attractive.

The question of ventilation receives careful attention. The kitchen is kept clean and tidy and is well equipped with an exceptionally good range.

The boys' dormitory is in separate building over class room. It is fairly well kept and clean. The inside decoration is not very attractive, the walls requiring attention by way of paint, etc. The ventilation is well attended to and amply provided for.

The building is heated by means of box stoves which are in good repair and smoke pipes are securely fixed.
Onion Lake Boarding School.

Hospital.

This building is situated some distance from the main school buildings. It is an old log building which has been fixed up for hospital purposes and is in good repair. The inner walls are exceptionally well plastered and clean, is properly lighted and ventilated.

The building is also heated by box stoves.

Gardens and Livestock.

I am unable to report on these as no proper information was obtainable at time of inspection. This will be fully reported upon at next inspection, as I hope to be able to see what is done in the gardens this coming summer.

Management.

It will be noted that there has been increased enrolment during the past year. The management and supervision, owing to the continued sickness of Rev. Mr. Matheson, is entirely looked after by Mrs. Matheson who also acts as doctor at Onion Lake Reserve. Her time is fully occupied and it cannot be expected that she would be able to devote much time to the supervision of the school as should be done.

Respectfully submitted,

Report on Inspection of Church of England Boarding School, Onion Lake, Sask.

Inspection visit was made on December 13th, 1917.

STAFF:

Mr. Henry Ellis Principal
Mrs. Ellis Matron

MANAGEMENT OF SCHOOL.

The management of this school was taken over by Mr. Henry Ellis in August, 1917. Previous to that date he was employed at the Blood Reserve Boarding School at which school Mrs. Ellis was a teacher. Mr. Ellis is a young man, who appears to possess business ability, is most enthusiastic in his work and I am of the opinion that with the assistance of Mrs. Ellis, who appears to be a competent matron, he will succeed in improving the living as well as the financial conditions of this school.

TEACHERS.

Miss Cunningham, who continues to teach at this school, I found to be as enthusiastic and as thorough as formerly. She keeps in touch with up-to-date methods of teaching which she applies in her work. Now that an assistant teacher has been engaged, Miss Cunningham will be able to devote more of her time to the advanced grades for which work she is fully competent and the results obtained by her are exceptionally good.
Teachers, contd.

Miss Leake, Assistant teacher, commenced her duties on December 1st, 1917. She has had former experience as a teacher of junior grades and is now taking charge of Grades I and II.

DAY PUPILS.

In addition to the Indian children there is an average of ten pupils who attend as day pupils, the majority of whom are the children of employees at Onion Lake Agency.
ADMISSIONS and DISCHARGES.

In December, 1916, the enrolment was 31 and since that time 5 children have been admitted and five discharged, leaving 34 pupils on roll at date of inspection. Of this number there were four applications awaiting the signature of parents and the approval of the Department. One pupil has been absent since the summer vacation on account of sore eyes.

HEALTH and CLOTHING.

At date of Inspection the general health of the pupils was good and they were provided with comfortable clothing.

EXAMINATION OF CLASSES.

Owing to alterations being made to school building the classes were being held in the Dining Hall and for this reason I was unable to make the usual examination of the class work. From what I observed, however, I feel satisfied that the same high standard as formerly is being maintained. In the evening I had the pleasure of witnessing a dress rehearsal of a Patriotic Pageant which the pupils were preparing for a concert to be given by them in aid of the Red Cross. The Indian children acquitted themselves well and much credit is due the teacher for encouraging the children to assist in this good cause.

CLASS ROOM.

The class room which is a large one was undergoing alterations at the time of my visit. The windows were being provided with storm sash and storm doors were also arranged for. The floor which is single boards and badly worn in places was being covered.
Class Room, contd. —
covered with fir flooring and the room divided
with a partition to provide two class rooms in
place of one as formerly. Box stoves were being
dispensed with and hot air registers were being in-
stalled to provide heat from hot air furnace in
course of construction in the basement. These much
needed improvements will convert the class room into
comfortable and desirable teaching quarters.

BUILDINGS.
The main building (photo attached marked "A")
consists of Dining Hall, Staff Dining Room and
Living Room, Kitchen, Indian Waiting Room and
Principal's office downstairs, while upstairs is the
Girls' Dormitory and sleeping quarters for part of
the staff. This building is very old and the floor
in the large dining hall is in bad condition. The
children's dining room has been enlarged by the re-
moval of partitions and the room is also made use
of by the girls for sewing and recreation purposes.
The rooms are heated by box stoves and while the
stove pipes are securely fixed there is great danger
of fire from this source.

The Girls' Dormitory is 31 X 23 X 5 feet which
provides 5704 cubic feet, or according to regulations
accommodation for 1140 pupils, whereas the number
of girls enrolled is at present 14. The interior
conditions of this Dormitory are not at all inviting
as the walls require redecorating and the wood work
repainting. The room, however, is kept clean and
the fact of its being extra well ventilated offsets
the seeming overcrowding.
I discussed with the Principal the advisability of providing additional dormitory accommodation for the girls and he proposes to use part of the staff living quarters for this purpose. By removing a partition a room 19' 4" x 23' 4" x 8' or 3600 cubic feet can be provided. The walls, however, are sloping and the air space is therefore somewhat restricted. This room is not provided with a sufficient number of windows and in addition a proper ventilator would require to be installed. After alterations were made the accommodation provided would not make room for more than five pupils.

I note that Mr. Ellis has provided emergency pails filled with water to be used in case of fire.

The Boys' Dormitory is in the top or third floor of separate building (Photo attached marked "B") the ground floor being the class room while the second floor has teachers' quarters and two recreation rooms for the boys. The dormitory is now heated by hot air registers from hot air furnace which is supplemented by heat from the smoke pipe which runs up through the building to the chimney built on brackets in the boys' dormitory. The elimination of box stoves with their numerous stove pipes will now lessen the danger from fire. The dormitory is well provided with windows to which storms have recently been fitted, thus providing additional comfort. The dormitory is supplied with a large ventilator which provides ample ventilation. I discussed with Mr. Ellis the need of having additional fire escape facilities from this room in the event of exit by way of inside stairs being cut off. He agreed to provide exit from one of the windows over the roof of the balcony to outside stairs.
Buildings, contd. -

The interior conditions of this dormitory are not inviting and some of the beds which are old are not in very good shape. The room, however, is kept clean and tidy.

The measurements of this boys' dormitory are 35' x 25' x 10'4" which provides 9041 cubic feet of air space, or according to regulations accommodation for 16 pupils, whereas the total enrolment of boys is 20. This number, however I would not consider excessive in view of ventilation facilities in the dormitory.

ALTERATIONS and IMPROVEMENTS TO BUILDINGS.

The alterations to school building (marked "b" in attached photograph) which were in progress at the date of inspection are estimated to cost $1500. This sum includes the following:

- Excavation of Basement under building.
- Hot air furnace
- Cement foundation under building.
- 2 storm porches to outside doors.
- Storm windows and doors.
- New floor in class rooms and partition.
- New outside stairs and platforms.

GRANT EARNEING PUPILS and ACCOMMODATION.

His Lordship Bishop Newnham advises me that he would like to take up with the Department the question of getting permission to increase the number of pupils at this school to 40 provided the dormitory accommodation would permit after alterations proposed by the principal are made.

The rooms suggested for additional dormitory are at present used by Principal and his wife who figure on getting quarters in ground floor of Hospital Building if same were taken over by the mission or the Department.
Grant Earning Pupils, etc., contd.

It will be noted that the dormitory accommodation at present provided is being made use of to capacity and over. The proposed additional Girls' dormitory would provide accommodation for 5 girls. I would respectfully suggest that the total number of pupils should not be allowed over 37.

In conversation with Mr. Milligan regarding Mistawasis Day School I found that if the school were opened now the attendance would be very small and I suggested that as it would not be advisable to re-open the school under those conditions, it would be better to allow the Principal of the C. of E. Boarding School, Onion Lake, to recruit from children at Mistawasis for his school. In this way a saving would be effected.

CLASS ROOM EQUIPMENT.

The classes are furnished with a sufficient quantity of supplies and these are properly looked after by the teacher. The principal made a request for some new desks but I advised him to get along with what he had for the present. Now that the class room has been divided additional blackboard will be required and I would respectfully suggest that two pieces of Hyloplate 3' X 6' be furnished as soon as possible.

LIVE STOCK and GARDEN PROVINCE.

The live stock at the school while the former principal was in charge were understood to belong to the school. It now seems that the present principal found upon arrival that the school owned no live stock whatever. He has purchased a cow.
Live Stock, etc., Contd.—

cow and hopes to purchase more stock as his funds will allow. He is also without a team. The principal has also found it necessary to buy a considerable quantity of vegetables but hopes next year to be able to raise all the vegetables required for the school.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the schools included in the Union Lake Agency which I visited during the month of March last.

St. Barnabas Boarding School.

I made a short visit to this school on March 26th as my time would not permit me making a comprehensive inspection. I went through the school and found it clean and well kept. The children were looking well. The school buildings are in very bad state of repair, in fact the old building is in a tumbled down condition, floors uneven, owing to the building have settled badly. There is a very great need for a new school at this point. There are 38 pupils on the roll, which is practically all they can accommodate. They have two applicants on the waiting list and an additional six & saddles who have requested admittance. I am attaching hereto District scale of wages supplied the pupils. There is only fifty acres of land in connection with this institution which is altogether inadequate for their requirements and does not provide any facilities for farming or the grazing of a sufficient number of stock. Two cows were being milked at the time of my visit, two were being purchased at an early date and two more coming in next spring, which will give them six cows to supply milk for the coming summer months. I visited this school on February the 16th and inspected the buildings throughout. I also held a short examination in class-room work.

There are 46 pupils enrolled—29 boys and 17 girls. The present enrolment taxes the capacity of the school to its limit. This school is a popular one with the Indians and the Principal is continually turning down applications for admission owing to lack of room to accommodate them.

Two class-rooms are provided and each is in charge of a properly qualified teacher. The class standing of the pupils is as follows:

| Standard | Number |
|----------|--------|
| 1        | 15     |
| 2        | 13     |
| 3        | 12     |
| 4        | 11     |

The pupils appear to be making excellent progress in their classwork. A number of white children attend as day scholars and their example is an incentive to the Indian children.

The pupils had a clean and healthy appearance. The boys receive training as cadets and they look very smart in their military uniforms. The pupils were all well and warmly clad.

Apart from some individual cases of sickness the general health of the pupils has been good.

They are provided with an ample supply of nourishing food including meat and vegetables. There is however a shortage of milk supply. Only two cows were being milked at the time of my visit. This number will I am told be increased when spring arrives.

BUILDINGS

There are two separate buildings, one for the boys and the other for the girls. The latter building has already been reported upon as being old and in a rather poor condition. I can only add that its condition is not improving and a new school will be the only remedy.

I found the buildings clean and comfortably heated provided for the children.

STAFF

The Rev. Mr. Ellis is in charge as Principal. He is assisted by a man to take charge of the outdoor work, two teachers a cook and a housekeeper.

Mr. Ellis impresses me as being a capable manager.

The two Onion Lake Boarding schools are situated in a good centre of Indian population. I do not think that there would be much difficulty in obtaining a considerable increase in pupilage if they had the necessary accommodation.

I have the honour to be

Sir

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Ewers' report regarding his visit to the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School on the 23rd and 25th ultimo. The Inspector reports on the classroom activity, as follows:

I left some suggestions with the teacher which, I hope, may prove of benefit and result in better work being done.

"I feel that the character of the written work was hardly as good as I found it the year previous. Discipline was quite good in the junior room, and fairly good in the senior room. On the whole, I would say that the clause did not measure up as well this year as they did a year ago."

The Department trusts that the teachers will follow the suggestions made by the Inspector, with a view to improving the classroom work.

The Inspector, also, comments on the use of slates and states that one reason for this was the delay in the receipt of exercise books. In connection with this, I may say that the Department favours discarding the use of slates entirely and we are prepared to supply whatever quantity of scribblers, exercise books, etc., that may be required.

It is necessary that schools should anticipate their requirements and allow a reasonable length of time for filling the orders. With reference to your school, I might point out that the requisition did not reach the Department until September 3rd. I believe that it would be advisable to forward a requisition for supplies for the new school year when sending in the June quarter return. This action would permit the supplies being secured and forwarded while the pupils are absent on holidays.

I found discipline and supervision also of a high order.

Suggestions regarding teaching methods.

Methods to be used in Indian Schools are of necessity somewhat different to those employed in other schools. The period at which Indian children can absorb information in the abstract arrives at a more advanced age, with the result that primary methods particularly involve a larger use of concrete material, e.g., in number work Indian children must have the objects before their eyes, and work with them for a longer time than white children. This same idea applies in other subjects. A teacher with experience in Indian schools should if possible be retained in the work, as it takes considerable time to gain the necessary experience to teach Indians well. I had a conversation with the teachers, and left some suggestions, and am pleased to report improvement in conditions as to methods used. As to disciplinary methods, I would recommend a rather firmer hand in the senior room, although I noticed that this recommendation had already been carried out to some extent.

General comment: As Miss Sherstone was new both to the school and the profession, most of our time was spent in observing her work. The results of tests in spelling were good, but some weaknesses were noted in Grade V arithmetic. In a lesson in geography, while the pupils had a map in front of them, it seemed that there was too much detail given and expected, with the result that interest was lacking. The same criticism holds good for lessons in history where too much detail and text destroyed the interest of the pupils. Besides having to large a class, Miss Sherstone is handicapped by lack of experience and lack of first hand knowledge of the Sask. curriculum which she is more or less at sea. Although she tries hard, and carefully prepares her work, this latter will not be sufficient to make her task very difficult. Her lessons lack punch. The discipline of this classroom has slipped somewhat this year, and attention will have to be given to this problem as once she has a long talk with this teacher, and discussed her problems fully with her, leaving some suggestions for her guidance. It was unfortunate that she had to go into such difficult work her first year, and in a province where she is not acquainted with the curriculum. I strongly advise that only experienced teachers be hired in future.

With the large enrolment in this classroom, the teacher has no time to give to the individual problems and difficulties of the pupils, especially the weaker ones. As a result certain phases of the work are suffering, especially in the higher grades where the pupils must prepare for standard Departmental examinations.

Since my last visit here, an extra room has been opened. This has cut down the crowding somewhat, but not enough. Both the primary and intermediate rooms still have too heavy a curriculum for a teacher to do effective work. It was also felt that grades 111-711 were out of school too much at other work, and thereby handicapped the work of the teacher. I am not blaming any of the staff for this situation, but the intermediate classroom is not large enough to accommodate all the pupils enrolled therein at one time, so one grade has to stay out. A fourth room is urgently needed here.

I was pleased to note that the pupils were getting a more practical training, the boys in manual work and farming, the girls in house economy. A separate room is being opened for manual training, the equipment for which has already been purchased. Some fine work has been done by the pupils. The singing of the pupils was of a high standard.

It is to be regretted that there have been so many staff changes. There have been six different teachers employed in the last three years. There were three new teachers here last visit, and one of them was planning to quit at Easter. One of the additions this year was a young lady right out of normal school without any experience. She worked hard, and seemed to be doing good work; she had difficulty in adjusting herself to her new surroundings. I would strongly advise that in future only experienced teachers be engaged, as experience not necessarily being with Indians. This is the second case this type in two years, and the work of the school is bound to suffer therefore.

It was noted that the teachers here were using the Bask attendance register instead of your departmental register which was used in all other schools inspected this fall.

Dear Sir:

I wish to reply to your letter 115-1-6 dated the 19th ultimo.

Miss Gillespie, the junior teacher was employed here only on a temporary basis. She left last September and since then Mrs. Davies, an experienced teacher of years standing took her place. It is our intention, whenever possible, to secure certificated teachers or those holding a degree, as we did for years before the War. During these abnormal times, however, it is a case of securing the best teacher that is available. I think we have been successful in this.

I am not aware that we are using obsolete texts, nor has the Inspector drawn my attention to this matter. I expect to meet Mr. Bowes in the near future and will certainly take up this point with him. Visit to St. Albert's Indian Residential School, Band 9 April 1947.

Building: On my first visit in the absence of the Principal, Rev. Henry Ellis, I was shown over the premises by the nurse matron, Miss Jackson, who is a competent young woman. (She leads the school's Girl Guides in addition to a full load of other duties and seems to be a kind of deputy director of the institution.) The building is in good repair. Some re-decorating of the walls is going on—pupils do the work—and certain floors are being re-surfaced with a special coating.

Dormitories are well—almost too well!—filled. Plumbing appears to be adequate. Bed linen was neat and clean. Much of this is donated by the Women's Auxiliary of Ottawa. The money thus saved must amount to a very considerable sum.

The basements were clean and tidy, and the laundry, furnace, and food storage rooms appeared to be efficiently conducted.

The classrooms are really adjuncts of the auditorium. Movable partitions preclude the use of adequate blackboards. In most rooms the pupils are seated more closely than desirable.

Staff:
Miss Atwater - Senior room
Miss Stephen - Intermediate grades
Mrs. Ellis - Junior grades
Miss Hauser - Beginners.

All these teachers have certificates as such. All appear to be doing good work and getting at least average (for Indians) results. Possibly the most striking progress is being...
made in the beginners' class. Miss Heuer seeks constantly to learn and apply worthwhile new techniques.

Supplies: Some additional tools are needed. Action is being taken to forward these. More primary aids would always be welcome, e.g., action cards such as "Bring me your book," etc.

Vocational Training: There is weaving for the girls, but no manual training for boys. There are boys, however, who are allowed to make themselves useful in town. The results have been beneficial to behaviour and profitable for the boys.

Cadet Corps: This is the subject of a separate memorandum on file 1-1-17.

High School Students: 3 girls, 2 boys attend the local collegiate. Prince Albert does not offer a progressive curriculum. Pauline Gladstone, Grade 10, and Kathleen Mosquito, Grade 9, met me on Central Avenue. I saw the others in the residential school.

Food: This appears to be good and ample, even when not much more than 15¢ a meal is available. The penitentiary makes a gift of some vegetables. A patch of land to be exploited for school purposes would meet a variety of needs. In this connection I refer to my memorandum suggesting the acquisition of all or part of the moribund Canadian Vocational Training Centre at Prince Albert.

Dear Mr. Pilcher:

While I was in Regina I mentioned to Mr. Ostrender and to our recently appointed Supervisor of Construction, Mr. Morrison, the mystery of your kitchen hot water or rather cool water tank. I shall feel more comfortable when I have your assurance that the supply of hot water is ample.

Under separate cover there is going forward to you a supply of a booklet "Good Health for Canada's Indians" which all your teachers should find useful. One copy should go back to each home at the end of June. I think your teachers will find in the curriculum definite instructions concerning the teaching of many of the matters covered in this booklet. In our residential schools there is sometimes a tendency to regard the teaching of health habits, personal grooming, table manners, etc., as the work of the supervisors. Especially do some teachers consider that the care of clothing, equipment and property is the supervisor's duty. My observations in the schools and on the reserves convince me that the children cannot be "supervised" into taking such care. It is the classroom teacher who must begin the instructional processes and with the cooperation of the supervisor continue to the necessary degree of appreciation and habit.

...2
In the matter of the cupboards which some of your classrooms require, may I suggest some sort of reciprocity with Mr. Scrase and his Manual Training class. I pointed out to Mr. Stoddard some shelving in building #32 which could be made available for a number of purposes.

St. Alban's school is, in my opinion, well able to endure inspection by visitors. I do not regard it as "frozen" in its present pattern. As a girls' school there must be a limitation upon the number of pupils and the number of grades conducted. So far we have relied upon the presence of over-age girls to give leadership in housekeeping and other activities. The time may come when beginners of normal age and size may more conveniently be handled at All Saints School and the girls in your charge would thus be older and in higher grades, or you might have a beginners class of the "opportunity" type comprising older girls. This development would probably entail changes in the teaching and supervisory staff. The present staff seems well suited to the present pupilage. I look forward to a further discussion with you after you have had the school under observation for a few more months.

Kindest regards to yourself and your wife.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,

Superintendent of Education:

St. Albans Indian Residential School:

Duties elsewhere compelled me to restrict my attention to this school to a discussion with the Reverend Principal last Sunday evening.

I told him that I was disappointed to discover that the supper dishes were being washed in lukewarm water even after the installation of a new heater in the boiler room. He explained that it was the engineer's afternoon "off". It would appear that the kitchen staff consider that they have to keep out of the boiler room.

He told me that his ratio of staff to pupils was rather high as he had been employing laundry helpers so as to avoid the "half-day" system. I assured him he would not be accused of continuing the half-day system so long as there were desks for all pupils and so long as a reasonable amount of practical work in laundering, cooking, mending, etc., is required of pupils so that they become competent in the theory and practice of these household science subjects. Unfortunately, some of his staff do not appreciate the necessity or the method of integrating this work with the pupils' schooling in the classroom. We must assume that advice on this subject must be repeated year after year and the organization of schools must be examined periodically to check any retrogression.

If this school follows out this plan there is no need for it to carry pupils beyond grade four. The part-time service of enough older girls can be assured as long as there is a quota of the academically-retarded. We might, however, ask the two Reverend Principals to consider whether they could during the coming year arrange matters so that St. Albans would have only grades two three four and five, followed the next year by three, four, five and six — but definitely stopping there so that any who go on to grade seven would join the presumably larger classes in the junior high school grades at All Saints school. This would eliminate from St. Albans next September the beginners and first-graders who would be more likely victims if fire were to break out in St. Albans. It means also that
St. Albans would in September send on to All Saints only those junior pupils who cannot be properly assigned to a normal Grade Two class. St. Albans would have to receive from All Saints a quota of pupils to provide well-balanced classes in Grades Two, Three, Four and Five. They have at St. Albans three rooms which may be considered to have capacity of 40, 30, 30. Perhaps they should use the largest room for Grade Two. This year that room holds grades three and four. It could hold Grades four and five if it is desired to retain the pupils who are going on to Grade Five. Then the following year it would be filled with a Grades Five-Six class with the other rooms holding thirty grade four and thirty grade three pupils. High school girls in residence would constitute the surplus up to 105.

A copy of this memorandum is being sent to Mr. Supt. Jones so that he may invite the attention of the Principals to the proposed changes, and permit them to discuss the matter and to correspond with their headquarters. Both schools are expecting changes in staff, and future organization should be a factor in making replacements, particularly of the teaching staff.

One question has been asked on which a higher-level answer is sought; May the schools retain on the roll and receive the usual grants for pupils who have attained the age of sixteen and wish to continue to attend residential school although they are only at, say, grade five? St. Albans has a few older pupils whose return to their so-called homes would be disadvantageous.

It is noted that St. Albans has a radio-phonograph which might be useful in the classrooms. Presently it is situated in the staff lounge.

C.A.F. Clark
