I think this requires better supervision in the kitchen on the part of staff personnel. I hope to achieve this through changes that will be taking place this summer. I normally at least think it wise that kitchen staff have nothing to do with the boiler room. If the need should arise when the engineer is off duty, we can act accordingly.

Re employment of assistants in laundry, etc. On my appointment here I was informed that children ought not to be taken from class to do work and that assistants had been appointed to eliminate this situation. I am glad to know that the Department does not take such a rigid view of this matter as I am aware how necessary practical and adequate training in domestic science is for our girls. I think this can be achieved by training of girls in school hours within reasonable limits. I think that all our staff can learn to appreciate the need for integration of the academic and practical.

Re suggestion for introducing Grade 5. This proposal seems unnecessary in view of what has already been noted. In any case, the arrangement of the Saskatchewan course of studies with "A" and "B" courses taught in alternate years precludes the grouping of Grades 4 and 5. To follow the curriculum as set out it is necessary to group Grades 1 and 2 together, 3 and 4, and so forth.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6323, file 658-6, part 1)
Re fire hazard. The presence of very small children in our building does not, in my opinion, expose them to any unusual fire hazard. The dormitories for younger children have direct exits of a satisfactory kind. If there is doubt about the adequacy of fire exits the building should certainly not be used but the Fire Commissioner is satisfied on this point although, like myself, he would feel happier if certain additional improvements were made.

Re grants for pupils who have already reached their seventeenth year. (Age 16) If the Department sees fit to continue in some cases the provision of grants for these girls I should be very happy. I am sure that in certain cases the girls would benefit from an additional year at the school and certainly some have wanted to come back. In such cases, I should like to see a special sort of course provided in which there would be plenty of practical experience and also an opportunity to give some simple instruction in subjects like home nursing, handicrafts, etc. We are certainly prepared to do something like that here. I think that such a course would probably be of more value to the academically retarded than the Grade 5 course as laid down in the provincial curriculum.

Re radio-phonograph. The radio-phonograph is kept in the staff lounge when not in use in the class-rooms or girls' play-room. The usual school broadcasts of C.B.C are used. Grades 3 and 4 have had an average of an hour per week. Grades 1 and 2 and the Primary group listen to a half-hour broadcast weekly and records are used for dancing, singing and general instruction. It is true to say that the machine is used much more for the girls than for the staff. The girls also listen in during some of their favorite programmes,...in their playroom. Perhaps we may look forward to being included in any circuit of recordings which may be arranged by the Department.
SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Onion Lake C.E. (St. Alban's) Indian Residential School

I visited this school briefly on Sunday, September 24, and had a discussion with the Principal.

There has been no change in the teaching staff but the former matron, Miss Jackson, is now at Moose Port Residential School and has been replaced at St. Alban's by Miss Twigg from Old Sun. Miss Twigg was succeeded at Old Sun by one of the teachers, Miss Moore. I always regret the transfer of competent classroom teachers to non-educational duties. It seems to me that matrons might rather be selected from women with experience as wives and mothers.

St. Alban's, as you are aware, is an all-girl school limiting its work to the first four grades. Earlier this year I suggested adding Grade 5 but the Principal and staff discussed technical objections based on curriculum requirements. The Principal now complains that it is difficult to get 100 girls in the first four grades whose families will permit them to be separated from their brothers and sisters at the Lac la Ronge School a mile away. The request that this should be a girls' school was made by the Church authorities and they should be encouraged to find a solution for filling their complement of pupils.

C.A.F. Clark
Educational Survey Officer.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT

SCHOOL: St. Alban's Indian Residential
PRINCIPAL: Mr. N.D. Pilcher.
LOCATION: 2028 Central Avenue, Prince Albert, Sask.
INSPECTION: May 10, 11, 1951.

GENERAL TONE AND PUPIL PROGRESS:
Days appear to be well scheduled and the pupils busy and happy at their work. The classes are receiving careful instruction and the pupil progress is generally quite satisfactory.

RECORDS GENERAL:
Office records of pupil standing are very limited. However, Principal Pilcher is planning this necessary data for next year. It is felt that Intelligence quotients for the older pupils at least should be on record.

OPPORTUNITY CLASSES:
This very desirable feature of Indian education is impossible because of limited space. It is believed that a number of the girls would benefit greatly by being in a class designed for optimum individual progress and development.

PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND RECREATION:
Rather limited during most of the school year by lack of playroom space. The only available floor space for this valuable feature lies between classrooms and the partitions offer no soundproofing which makes it impossible for classes to exercise during the school day. Evening recreation for these pupils is very limited by lack of space.

ORGANIZED GAMES:
It is difficult to realize much in this field with girls in Grades I - IV. However, it is hoped that a girls softball team may be organized to compete with other public school teams.

LIBRARY WORK:
There is no available space for recreational reading and library activities. Some library material is available in each classroom, but here again limited space makes it difficult to encourage pupil reading. It is felt that an essential feature of this work is an attractive display of books and materials.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING:
The girls have been doing very good work in sewing under the direction of Mrs. A.I. Wood. Many practical garments have been made which will be used by the girls. It is regretted that Mrs. Wood is seriously ill and may not be able to complete the work planned for this term.

PUPIL DRESS AND COMFORT:
The girls are cleanly and comfortably clothed. There are no unpleasant odors in the crowded classrooms.
INSPECTOR'S REPORT

ST. ALBAN'S SCHOOL (Continued)

(2)

CLASSROOM ACCOMMODATION:

As indicated in the attached forms classroom space is quite inadequate. A careful study of the whole building would indicate that there is no neat solution of this problem. This situation is serious and worthy of special consideration by Departmental and Church authorities.

DINING ROOM AND KITCHEN SERVICE:

These rooms are clean and made as attractive as limited space will allow. Although no meals were taken with the pupils it is my impression that the pupils are properly nourished.

DORMITORIES:

The sleeping quarters are generally satisfactory. However, sections accommodating the smaller girls are overcrowded. The washroom and toilet facilities are quite inadequate throughout. The dormitories are neat and tidy and the bedclothing is clean. It is felt that staff supervision in the older girls section might be improved, but here again, lack of accommodation presents a problem.

HOSTEL AND HIGH SCHOOL WORK:

This feature of Indian Education is difficult to administer and the results thus far are not too encouraging. Two girls were enrolled in Grades IX and XII at the Prince Albert Collegiate last fall opening. The Grade XII student was forced to drop out at Christmas by a personal difficulty; the Grade IX pupil is still attending, but her Collegiate record for the year indicates a June failure. See comments under this heading in All Saints School Report.

REMARKS RELATIVE TO METHODS EMPLOYED BY TEACHER.

Classes in number work were observed. In Grade 1 the addition and subtraction facts of 5 and 4 were taught, with apparently little interest being aroused in the children by the teacher. In Grades II and III there did not seem to be any definite aim in the number work taken up. There was not any seat work activity provided for the pupils who were not receiving instruction. An examination of exercise books indicated that very little work was being accomplished in this school.

ATTENDANCE PROBLEMS.

Twenty-one pupils were enrolled, but only twelve being in attendance on the morning of my inspection. Five of the children present belonged to the Roman Catholic religion. There are five children of the Church of England denomination attending the Onion Lake Indian Residential School. Mr. Mullens appeared more concerned about the attendance of these few Protestant children at the Onion Lake Residential School than the non-attendance of the nine children of his own school. I asked Mr. Davis, Indian Superintendent, and Mr. Grant, Assistant, who were present to look into the whereabouts of the absentees, and to enforce the attendance of those not ill, at school.

GENERAL REMARKS.

The general condition of the school is most unsatisfactory. Although the new school building under construction, there is no reason why the present classrooms should be permitted to become so dirty and untidy. If the primary objective of the elementary school is to assist the child to enjoy and to appreciate health and healthful living and to promote the interests of health in the community, then this school is not in any way performing its duty in this respect. November 15th, 1919.

Dear Father Grandin -

I have your letter of the 5th instant, regarding the Bugler children at present in the Onion Lake Church of England boarding school. The letter to which you refer was sent without my knowledge, but I have looked carefully into the matter and I am of the opinion that the action taken in that letter was consistent with the circumstances as known to the Department.

These children were placed voluntarily in the school by their parents - one of the girls so long ago as 1912 and the other three years ago - and it was only recently, after this long interval, that the request was made to have them transferred.

I can assure you that it is my wish to deal fairly with all concerned in matters of this kind, but we cannot adopt the view that every change of religion by the parents should create an obligation on the Department to transfer their children from one school to another.

I regret, therefore, that the request for this transfer cannot be complied with.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

I beg the permission of discussing again the transfer of Jos. Bugler's daughters from Onion Lake to the Delmas School. The Department has refused to do it, last year, but we are convinced that the case was not put properly, before the proper authorities.

Let us first lay down some fundamental principles that will guide in this discussion:

a) Liberty of Conscience. This principle is accepted all over the world. Jos. Bugler had perfect right to sever his connection with the Church of England to join the Catholic Church.

b) The most sacred rights of the parents over their children is the right of giving them an education in conformity with their own religious conviction. This is a natural right.

c) It is immaterial to your Department whether an Indian is a Catholic or a non-Catholic, or in what particular denominational Indian School the Indian children are educated.

d) It is admitted by all ligists that where there is conflict between two laws viz., between a natural law and a manmade law, the natural law has the preference over the other; so much more so, when a Government Departmental regulation comes into conflict with the natural law.

e) There is no clause in the Indian Act to forbid an Indian to use any intermediary to negotiate his affairs with the Department; and if there was such a clause, it would certainly be unjust, therefore not binding.

In the light of the above principles, it should be easy to bring to a fair settlement, this Bugler affair.

Put yourself in the place of Jos. Bugler, and also recall to your memory this great command of Our Lord: "Do ye to others what you want them to do to you". How would you like to have your parental right disregarded as they are in this case?

Jos. Bugler has always been a very obedient and respectful Indian. He has always tried to work in cooperation with his Agent and his Instructor. When he was a member of the Church of England, he was the right hand of Mr. Pink; he very often neglected his own work to go and do Mr. Pink's work, and this old gentleman was never afraid of advancing him all the food he was in need of. But as soon as he joined the Catholic Church (it was during the Spanish flu) Mr. Pink would have seen him with pleasure starve to death with all his family.

Mr. Pink who was always more anxious to promote the interests of his Church on the Red Pheasant Reserve, than to do the work which he was supposed to do, made it a duty of his religious zeal to make Jos. Bugler feel that he had done a very wrong action in changing religion.

In my letter of the 18th Aug. 1919, I was perfectly right in stating that the Bugler girls were not being sent home because of the eventuality of them becoming Catholic. Mr. Commissioner Graham forwards copies of correspondence regarding the transfer of Eva and Edna Bugler, daughters of Joseph Bugler, No. 301 of the Red Pheasants Band, from the Onion Lake (C.E.) Boarding School to the Thunderchild's Boarding School.

The records in connection with this case are as follows:- Eva was admitted to the Battleford Industrial School at six years of age in 1912, and, upon the closing of that school, was sent to the Onion Lake (C.E.) Boarding School in August, 1917, where she has been a pupil up to the present summer holidays. She is now fourteen years of age. Her sister, Edna, was admitted to the Onion Lake (C.E.) School on September 1st, 1916, to replace her brother Louis, who was granted his discharge. The applications for the admission of both these girls are signed by the father and on the application for Eva her religion is stated to be Anglican, while on that for Edna it is stated to be "Protestant". Both these girls have been pupils in the Onion Lake School since the date of their admission - Eva for six and Edna for four years - and no question was raised regarding their religion. Father Lacon of the Thunderchild's School now claims that the father has become a Roman Catholic and has severed his connection with the Church of England and wants the two girls sent to the Thunderchild's Boarding School. They were both allowed home on a holiday and Father Lacon has advised the father to refuse to return them to Onion Lake and now asks that they be allowed to enter his school. A protest has been received from the Principal of the Onion Lake (C.E.) School against their admission to Thunderchild's and he asks that steps be taken to have them returned to his school.

While the father has, no doubt, the right to change his religion, yet, it seems to me that, as these girls have been for a number of years in the Anglican School, they should remain there.
there. If we allow the transfer of these girls to the Thunderchild's School because the father has changed his religion it will open the door to considerable trouble in similar cases in future, as the Indian parents change their religion with great frequency. I consider that when a child has been in a school for a year or more without any question being raised as to the religion that, although the parents afterwards change their views, the child should remain in the school to which he was first sent. The two girls above mentioned should be returned to the Onion Lake (S.E.) Boarding School, and I would advise that Commissioner Graham be requested to instruct Mr. Agent Macdonald of the Battleford Agency to take the necessary steps to have them returned as soon as possible.

On October 1st 1923, I was notified by Mr. L. Turner, Indian Agent, Onion Lake Agency, that the two above mentioned Indian boys had left the Church of England Mission School without permission, and he requested me to assist in overtaking the boys.

I patrolled with saddle horse 1682 to the districts immediately surrounding Onion Lake on the 1st of October and by courtesy of Mr. Ellis the Principal of the School I was given the use of an Automobile with which I patrolled the same evening to Frog Lake, and in the morning I located the boys at the home of Mr. Charles Quinney, the Indian School Teacher at Frog Lake, who had very kindly taken the boys in about dark, and had induced the boys to stay till I was enabled to learn their whereabouts, and return them to the School.

No extraordinary expense was incurred on this patrol.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

The Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of our Society's School at Onion Lake, has forwarded to me a copy of your letter (File No. 115-1-10) of Dec. 29, addressed to him, and a copy of his reply. As the question referred to in this correspondence, namely, the transfer of the pupil Augustine Steinhauser, from the Onion Lake School to the new Methodist School at Edmonton is liable, as Mr. Ellis has pointed out, to be followed by the transfer of other pupils, I beg to request that this transfer not be allowed until after we have had an opportunity of further discussing this subject towards the end of February, when I expect to be in Ottawa. I am extremely anxious that no situation should be allowed to develop which might open the way for almost interminable difficulties in the way of requests for transfer.

Already a number of Indian parents who are members of the Church of England but have children in the Brandon and Portage la Prairie institutions, have requested that their children be transferred to Elkhorn as soon as that school is opened. In response to their request they have not, up to the present, received any encouragement, our Society having agreed to the following opinion expressed by Mr. Scott in a letter addressed to Canon Gould, our General Secretary, on Oct. 18, 1922, in connexion with this subject:

"I believe that a child that has been resident in a school and may have imbibed religious opinions should remain in that school for the full tuition period."

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Agent Pugh advises the Department that you have written him with reference to having Noah and Homer Houle, who were allowed home on holidays from the Onion Lake Residential School, returned.

Residential School to Edmonton, the guardian of the Houle children made a special request that they also be sent to Edmonton. Although he had no authority from the Department to do this, the agent states that, as these children are Methodists and as the Edmonton school is the closest to the Saddle Lake Agency, he felt it advisable to accede to the guardian's request.

If this matter had been referred to the Department you would have been consulted before the transfer was authorized, but I believe that the agent, in taking this action, felt that, for the reasons stated, he was justified in transferring them and had no desire to deprive the Onion Lake school of the pupils to which it was entitled.

Please let me know if you insist on the return of the Houle children to Onion Lake. If you can recruit up to strength, it might be well to allow the matter to stand as at present.

Our obedient servant,

On the night of October 16th 1924, I was requested by Mr. L. Turner, Indian Agent, Onion Lake Agency to patrol in search of two Indian boys by the name of George Quinney and Johnny Mathias who had that evening left the Protestant Mission School without permission.

By arrangement with Mr. J. Wright of the Mission staff I left immediately with him in the Car and patrolled to Frog Lake Reserve where I notified the Parents that the boys had left the School without permission.

The following day I made a thorough search of the Reserve and vicinity but without locating the boys, and on my return to the Pleasure Office at Frog Lake found Mr. Mathias waiting me to inform me that the boys had returned to the School that morning.

I returned to Onion Lake the following morning, the 18th instant.

Cpl.

REPORT re
Joseph Cross - Frog Lake Indian Reserve, Alberta.
INDIAN ACT.

On March 3rd 1925 I received a complaint from
the Farm Instructor at the Church of England Mission
at Onion Lake to the effect that one of the Mission
boys by the name of Joseph Cross had run away from
the School.

The Farm Instructor, Mr Mitchell, acting for
the Principal who was away, informed me that the boy
was about seventeen years of age, and that he would
like our assistance to bring him back.

I got in touch with the Indian Agent, Mr L.
Turner for the necessary authority to make a patrol
to Frog Lake to bring this boy back, pointing out to
him that the boy was over School age; and Mr Turner
requested that we endeavour to do so.

I detailed Reg No 9464, Cst Peacock D., to pat-
rol there forthwith, and by arrangement he did so
with the Mission team, arriving the same day at Frog
Lake.

On the 4th instant he patrolled to the Indian
Reserve and to the camp where Joseph Cross was with
his Uncle Sam Napayo, an Indian of the Frog Lake Band
and asked for the boy.

His Uncle Sam Napayo informed Cst Peacock that
the boy was then out looking for the horses and that
as soon as they were found that he would personally
return the boy to the School - which he did.

Cst Peacock returned to Onion Lake Detachment
the same day.

Reg No 6298, i/c detachment.

The Commissioner,
R.C.M.Police,
Ottawa, Ont.

REPORT re
John Matthias & George Peschowe, C.E.M.S. Mission.
Onion Lake, Sask. - Indian Act.

Ottawa Ref. No.

P.A.Ref. No.

A.N.477.

On May 10th 1925, it was reported to me by the Farm Instructor Mr. F. Booth that two boys were missing from the above Mission School and that the Instructor at the Mission had applied for assistance in locating the boys.

I got in touch with Mr. Murison, Inspector of the Department of Indian Affairs at the Onion Lake Agency and he, in the absence of the Agent Mr. L. Turner, asked me to make an effort to locate the boys and to return them to the School.

I forthwith accompanied Mr. Mitchell, Instructor at the Mission to the Frog Lake District by private Car where I visited the few Indians remaining on the Reserve, and notified them to hold the boys for me when they should arrive.

I returned to the Frog Lake Hamlet for the night and the following day I returned to the Reserve and met an Indian girl coming to meet us with the boys who had turned up at the Reserve during the night.

I returned the boys to the School the same day.

REPORT No

CHARLES QUINNEY - Onion Lake Indian Reserve.
INDIAN A.G.T.A.

Ottawa Ref. No.

P.A. Ref. No.

A.N.538.

On Sunday, September 13th 1926, I received a complaint from Mr T.Mitchell acting on behalf of the Principal of the Protestant Mission School at Onion Lake, to the effect that the above named Indian boy had left the Mission School without leave and when located at his Uncle's camp on the Indian Reserve on the 10th instant had refused to return before seeing his father, who is a Widower with no fixed home for his children except the Mission School.

I accompanied Mr Mitchell in private Car to the Camp on the Indian Reserve and met Joseph Quinney the father of the boy Charles Quinney and asked him to surrender the boy to the School, which he did forthwith, at the same time making complaints which Mr Mitchell instructed him to make to the Principal Mr H.Ellis.

Joseph Quinney stated that he had repeatedly made complaints to the Principal without result and that he should complain to the Indian Agent, especially as to the food and clothing supplied to the boy and of which he had complained to his father; this being his reason for leaving the School without permission.

No expenditure was incurred in this connection.

Reg No 6298, 1/6 of Detachment.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, No. 115-1-10, in connection with the application for admission of Louise Quinney to the Onion Lake Church of England Residential School.

In explanation of this application I beg to say that the child in question was given to Angus Quinney, upon the death of her mother, and at the age of four years. Angus Quinney kept her and she was living the Indian mode of life on the Saddle Lake Reserve until she was six years old, when she was taken into the Onion Lake school. She is now eight years old and Quinney is anxious to have her admitted as a grant-earning pupil. Quinney says he is very fond of the child and that he did not adopt her merely for the purpose of having her admitted to the school.

In view of the circumstances I beg to request that she be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Acting on instructions received from the Officer Commanding 5th Division, on the morning of the 16th Inst last, I left Prince Albert on the same morning by C.N.R. and proceeded to Leask, Sask., escorting an Indian boy by the name of John Ermina, of the Sturgeon Lake reserve; on my arrival at Leask I was met by Mr John Weir, Indian Agent, and Mr Carleton Agency and proceeded to Mistawasis reserve.

On my arrival there I arrested Willie Head, of Mistawasis reserve, another boy who had run away from the above named school. I held both boys at the agency until the morning of the 16th inst last.

On that date I left Leask by C.N.R. and escorted the two boys to Lloydminster, Via Saskatoon. On my arrival in Lloydminster at 12-45 A.M. I was informed by J. McNeil there that Corp. Pearson was away from home, and that he was not expected home till the afternoon.

Before I left Leask I wired Mr Elkin principal of the Onion Lake school that I would arrive on the train that night, there was a car in from the school to meet the train, so I proceeded to Onion Lake right away. On my arrival I handed the two boys over to the Principal and received a receipt in return.

I returned to Lloydminster that same day, and left for Prince Albert on the following morning by C.N.R. Via Saskatoon.

I have the honour to enclose herewith an application for the admission of Christina Emma Quinney, to the Onion Lake Church of England Residential School.

This child is the daughter of a widowed Indian woman, Harriett Quinney, of Frog Lake band. Three other children have been already admitted to the school and, as having Christina with her prevented her from earning her living by going out, and working for settlers, Mr. Ellis, the principal of the school, agreed to accept the child on condition that I would recommend her admission; and I am pleased to do so.

The child is very young for admission but I hope the Department will make an exception in this case and authorize the admission.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, October 19th, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the September quarter return of the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School. In reply I beg to say that the discharge of the following pupils is approved:

No. 121 Peter Wuttunnee, No. 098 Helen Wuttunnee,
" 122 Solomon Ballantine, " 099 Flora Snakeskin,
" 123 John Ballantine, " 0100 Mary Alec.

The Department finds it necessary to send back this return as the Principal has not stated the dates between which the annual holidays were taken and we are, therefore, unable to decide if the proper grant has been requested. I desire to refer particularly in this regard to pupils 55, 59, 62, 84, 87, 103, 106, 112, 114, 116, 032, 045, 064, 065, 066, 071, 076, 078, 079 and 084.

None of these pupils are shown to have attended in the classroom during the quarter. If the annual holidays began on July 1st and these children have not yet returned to the school, grant should only be requested for 45 days for each of them. In preparing the September quarter return form should only be written for each pupil for the actual number of days such pupil was in residence during the quarter plus 45 days holidays, for which grant is allowed. You should take up this matter with the Principal and have this return properly completed.

I would also point out that no applications or certificates of health have yet been received for No. 121, 122, 123, 098, 099, 0100, 0101, 0102, 0103 and 0104. When sending back the return the applications for these children should also be forwarded.

A duplicate copy of this letter is enclosed, which you should hand to the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

L. Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Prince Albert, Sask.
October 23rd, 1926.

Re: Annie & Gilbert Brown - Sandy Lake Indian Reserve.
Absentees from Onion Lake Indian School, Onion Lake.

Acting on instructions from the Officer Commanding
on the morning of the 20th instant, I left Prince Albert
by C.H.R. train for Leask. I was met at the train by
Indian Agent J. Weir and we proceeded by auto to Sandy Lake.

I made enquiries for James Brown, father, of the
above named children, and was informed that he was
working in the vicinity of Onion Lake. The following day
we proceeded to Onion Lake and succeeded in locating
Brown camped three miles outside of the town. I informed
him that we had come for the children, Annie and Gilbert,
as they had to return to the School at Onion Lake; he
did not wish the children to go although the children
stated that they wanted to return to the School.

On my request the Girl and Boy dressed and
accompanied Indian Agent Weir and myself to the
Agency at Mistawasis, where they were handed over to
Henry Ellis, Principal, Onion Lake Indian School.

Mr. Ellis had with him six other Indian children
for the school, and at his request I went with him to
the Railway station at Leask on the morning of the
22nd and saw that they boarded the train.

J. McNeil, Corp.
Reg. No. 5948.

The Commissioner.
R.C.M.Police.
Ottawa, Ont.

Forwarded for his information. Copy sent
to Indian Agent, J. Weir, Leask, Sask. Case concluded.

Prince Albert,
25-10-26.

S. L. Lamontagne, Supt.
Commanding "A" Division.

Acting on instructions received from the Officer Commanding "F" Division. On the morning of the 4th instant I left Prince Albert by automobile and proceeded to Sturgeon Lake Indian Reservation, for the purpose of detaining the above named boy and returning with him to Prince Albert.

On my arrival at Sturgeon Lake Reserve in the P.M., I went to the residence of Farm Instructor A. Gregson and was informed by his wife that Mr. Gregson was away visiting the new Sturgeon Lake Reserve, and that she did not expect him back till evening.

I next proceeded to the residence of John Ermina and was informed by his mother that he was away from home working on a thrashing outfit owned by J. Colfar, that Mr. Colfar was thrashing the farmers grain in the Sturgeon Valley District some 10 miles away. I next proceeded to the Sturgeon Valley District and making considerable enquiries along the road was informed that J. Colfar was thrashing for B. Salisbury who had returned to Prince Albert by train. I proceeded to this location at which place Mr. Colfar was thrashing and where I located John Ermina. I took this lad to Mr. Colfar and stated that I had to take him away from his employ and requested that he pay the boy his wages which he did.

I next returned to the home of John Ermina, where he changed clothes, his mother and father stating that they were not going to let the boy come with me, I took no notice of this and told them if they had any grievances about this lad going to school they had better take it up with Mr. Weir their Agent. I then went with the lad to the Farm Instructor's Residence where I saw Mr. Gregson who had returned, and I received from him a transport requisition for this lad transportation to Lloydminster.

I then left Sturgeon Lake Reserve with John Ermina and proceeded to Prince Albert arriving at 10.00 P.M. on the same date.

68 miles was travelled on this trip.

Dear Sir:- Re - Expenditure incurred in returning pupils to
the Onion Lake School after summer holidays.

I have received your letter of the 22nd instant,
(115-1-10) pertaining to the expenditure incurred in having pupils
returned to our Onion Lake School after the summer holidays. The
vouchers are going forward today to Mr. Ellis with a request that
he should take the matter up with the local Indian Agent in
accordance with your instructions, and you will no doubt hear
further from your representative in this connection.

In the meantime I trust you may not consider our request
for assistance in meeting the cost of an escort for these children
as either unfair or unreasonable. In the first place the School
is situated 40 miles from the railway with a wide river to be
crossed on the way. Until a heavy truck was provided the labour
and anxiety and expense which fell upon the School management in
transporting the children out and back over this distance has been
much greater than can be readily appreciated. From Lloydminster
many of the children had a long railway journey to their homes
and changed from one train to another at Battleford. To the
Principal, and I may add, to our Commission also, it seemed that an
escort should be provided for this part of the journey also.
Hitherto the cost of an escort has been provided by our Society and
our Commission very earnestly desire you to assist them as much
as may be in your power in meeting this expenditure in the future.
If a fixed sum, say of $250, were included in your annual
appropriation for this specific purpose, leaving our Society to
meet any expenditure incurred over that amount, it would probably
meet the needs of the case. If this total amount were not required
it would not, of course, be expended.

Commending this suggestion to your favourable consideration, I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, November 30th, 1927.

Sir,

Indian Residential School dated the 3rd instant, has drawn attention to the case of Annie Bird, sixteen years of age, who has been troubled with glands for some years. REPORT

Re - Charles Minney - Onion Lake, Sask;
Indian Bay - Absentee from school.
Re - Long Turner - Indian Agent - Complaint of.

First Report:

Whilst on duty at Onion Lake on the 5th inst., I was requested by Long Turner, the Indian agent there, to interview Joe Minney, father of the above mentioned, with reference to his taking his boy away from the Anglican Residential School at Onion Lake, and if possible try to get the boy and take him back to the school.

I patrolled to west of Onion Lake to locate Joe Minney, who I was informed was getting hay in that district. I eventually located his camp, but there was no one around there and on making further enquiries, was informed that Joe Minney had gone to the residential school to interview the Rev Mr Ellis, the Principal, to have the boy returned there.

It appeared from information received that Joe Minney had taken the boy away from the school for help to get in hay, but that they had quarrelled and he then wanted the boy to return, but the boy had left him.

I was unable to locate either Joe Minney or the boy on that occasion, but I left word that Joe Minney was to take the boy back to the school immediately on his return. I reported this to Mr Turner, and he was to return me, should this not be done. Up to the present time I have not heard from Mr Turner, and have no doubt that the boy has been returned to the school.

I intend however, to take up this matter again when next on duty at Onion Lake.

H. Fielder

RE: TRUANT INDIAN CHILDREN - Onion Lake School

We have a few children who are absent without leave from the Anglican Indian Residential School at Onion Lake residing in the Carlton Indian Agency.

An escort from this school has been to the Agency twice, but the children have not reported in order that they could be taken back to the school after their mid-summer vacation.

I will be obliged if you will send a constable (to act as truant officer) as soon as possible to report to Mr. Indian Agent "Sir at Leask, Sask.", from whom the constable will receive his instructions to apprehend these children.

It will not be necessary to escort these children as they can be placed in the care of the train conductor and met at North Battleford. The Indian Agent has arranged to notify me the day before the children board the train.

Yours very truly,

REPORT

RE - TRUANT INDIAN CHILDREN -
ONION LAKE SCHOOL, SASK.

6-11-28

Accompanied by Cst Patzwald I proceeded from Prince Albert to Mistawasis Indian Reserve by Police Car and interviewed Mr Weir, Indian Agent, in the above connection. Mr Weir furnished me with a list of names of children who had not reported back to school.

I proceeded to Sandy Lake Reserve and located Flora Ahanekeew and Emma Bird with the assistance of the Farm Instructor; these two girls I escorted to Mistawasis and left them overnight at the house of Mr Fred Brover, Interpreter, whilst Cst Patzwald and myself proceeded to the hotel at Leask.

7-11-28

I proceeded to Mistawasis Reserve and located Bella Starblanket, picked up Flora Ahanekeew & Emma Bird and returned with the three to Leask where I placed them on the train for North Battleford in charge of the Conductor.

Cst Patzwald and myself then returned to Prince Albert.

Dear Sir:-

Re: the attendance of pupils and grant for the Onion Lake School C.of E. Sept. quarter, 1928

My attention has been directed to the grant paid by your Department for the Sept. Quarter, 1928, for our Onion Lake School, the attendance for that period, according to the report of the Principal, being 71 but the grant allowed being furnished for an average attendance of 69.36.

From a letter recently received from the Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of this School, it would appear that five children from the Carlton Agency at Leask, who had been in residence at his school "for four years and more", were transferred by order of your Department to the File Hills School, without any reference to him whatever. The names of the children are as follows:-

#91 Samuel Dreaver Age 14 years -
#61 Lydia Dreaver " 13 "
#99 Ivan Dreaver " 14 "
#68 Christie Dreaver " 16 "
#69 Mary Dreaver " 12 "

As the above pupils were in attendance at our Onion Lake School at the end of the June Quarter when a grant was allowed for 80 pupils, it appears to me that their absence from the School during the September Quarter, apparently by order of your Department, and without the admission of other pupils to take their place, is responsible for the reduction in the grant for that period.
As the transfer of pupils from one school to another does not harmonize with the wishes of your Department, so far as I understand them, I am wondering if any mistake has been made in this matter by the Indian Commissioner, on whose authority it would appear the transfer was effected.

I shall be grateful, therefore, for any explanation you may be able to furnish in this connection, and for a reconsideration of the amount of the grant which our Society should have received for the September Quarter. So far as our Commission can see, and they have given their careful consideration to this matter, they are of the opinion that the grant should certainly have been paid for an attendance of not less than 71. They were also of the opinion that when pupils are removed, as those mentioned appear to have been, by an order from your Department, without giving our Society an opportunity of replacing them, the grant should be paid on the basis of the average attendance for the last previous Quarter.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

My attention has been drawn to your 303-11B of the 29th ultimo, regarding the Dreaer children of the Mistawasis reserve. This summer, when you brought to my notice Dreaer's request for a transfer of his children from the Onion Lake to the File Hills Indian Residential School, I understood that they had recently been admitted to the former institution. I find that such is not the case, and I now believe his request should not have been granted. These children had been at the Onion Lake School for some time, and the Department does not transfer children on religious grounds. Further, the File Hills School is not Presbyterian but United Church.

Evidently, William Dreaer did not intend to send his children to File Hills. I find that only two of them are registered there, and I am satisfied that those that are still on the Mistawasis reserve should be returned to Onion Lake. If you concur, please take steps to this end without delay and let me have a report concerning your action. I agree that it would be a mistake to take these children from boarding school and enroll them at the Mistawasis Bay School. Your remarks regarding the Rev. Mr. Moore have been noted.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

After again reviewing very carefully all the information received regarding this application, the Department is requesting Mr. Agent Turner to inform Rev. Mr. Ellis that we are not prepared to approve the admission of Louis Francis Harper to the Onion Lake C. E. Residential School at the present time and that he should be returned to his father.

The eligibility of this boy, on religious grounds, was doubtful and, in view of the instructions contained in circular letter of November 12th, 1926, it is felt that Rev. Mr. Ellis should not have allowed him to remain at the Onion Lake C. E. School.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 8th, 1929.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th ultimo with further reference to the application for the admission of Louis François Harper to the Onion Lake C. E. Residential School.

The Department considers that it is in the best interests of all concerned to adhere as strictly as possible to the intention of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act. The original application stated that the religion of this boy is Roman Catholic and, while the father's statement contained in your recent letter conveys the intimation that he is considering joining the Anglican Church, the Department feels that it must be kept in mind that the father, up to the present, considered himself a Roman Catholic by placing his girl in the Onion Lake R. C. Residential School. His opinion that the one school is better for boys cannot be considered.

The Department is not prepared to approve the admission of this boy to the Onion Lake C. E. Residential School at the present time and it is considered that he should be returned to his father at once. Please inform Rev. Mr. Ellis accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 8th inst., No.115-1-10, stating that you were not prepared to approve the admission of Louis Francis Harper to this school at the present time, and requesting that he be returned to his father, reached me here yesterday, and in reply I beg to state that action has already been taken in keeping with your request.

I saw this pupil's father this morning, and after explaining to him the contents of your letter, arranged for the Principal to place the boy in his possession. As the father emphatically declared that he will never send this boy to the Roman Catholic School, and has already forwarded to your Department an affidavit setting forth his desire to have him admitted to and educated in our Society's School, your decision in this connection is quite as perplexing to him as it is to me. His perplexity in this matter is further intensified by the fact that he requested the Principal of our Society's School here to admit this boy to membership in the Church of England, and this admission has already taken place. I have talked the situation over today with Mr. Indian Agent Turner, and recommended to him, when until further notice, the request of the Father that the boy be permitted to attend our Society's School as a day pupil be granted, and Mr. Turner agreed to support this recommendation. Mr. Turner will, I understand, write to you in this connection. I further recommended to Mr. Indian Agent Turner that a strong effort be made to have the question of the admission of this boy to our Society's School as a grant-earning pupil, finally decided at an early date, and gave it as my opinion that this decision should be reached not later than the middle of August, when the school will reopen after the summer holidays. Mr. Turner agreed to this recommendation, and will, I believe, write you accordingly.

School for the month of October, in which he states that three halfbreed children are in residence at the school temporarily. We have the situation pretty well cleared up with regard to getting halfbreed children out of the schools who were in without authority, and if we are not very careful it will only be a short time before we are having the same difficulty again.

Sir:-

With reference to your letter of the 20th ultimo concerning the admission of halfbreed children into the Onion Lake Anglican School, I note that the Department does not appear to have any correspondence making application for the admission of such children. The Agent informs me that these children were entered on the authority of Dr. Westgate, and I do not think this is a matter which should be treated lightly. I would ask that Doctor Westgate be written to by the Department in this regard, and, if it is the Department's wish, the children should be discharged at once. The Agent is endeavoring to get in communication with the parents of these children. It has been a hard struggle to keep halfbreeds out of our schools and if we are going to make exceptions and admit a few we are going to have a lot of trouble.

Your obedient servant,

With reference to Department No. 115-1-10 of the 11th instant, in regard to three half-breed children admitted without authority as pupils at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School, I have to state that they first entered the school in February, 1928, coming from Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan. Their mother had just died and their father asked to have them placed in the school temporarily. Mr. Ellis, however, lost all trace of the father, but finally located him and he promised to take the children away. He has not done so and Mr. Ellis is in communication with him and expects that he will come and take the children away soon. I note in the Agent's report for the month of November that they are still in residence, and, as it is not the intention of the Department to educate them, if the father does not take them away and look after them they should be transferred to the Department of Neglected and Dependent Children.

We are frequently being asked to allow the admission of half-breed children to our Indian schools and are as constantly refusing, and the Reverend Canon Westgate should not have informed the Principal that they could be admitted, as their cases were evidently ones which should have been dealt with by Provincial authorities and not by the Indian Department.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:—

I am forwarding herewith Indian Agent Turner's reports on the R.C. and C. of E. Indian Residential Schools in the Onion Lake Agency, also reports in the Day Schools.

I would draw your attention to the fact that the three Lawrence children are still in residence at the R.C. School, and the three Peterson children at the C. of E. School. These children should be discharged and handed over to the proper authorities, as they are certainly not a proper charge against the Department of Indian Affairs, being halfbreeds.

With reference to the Peterson children that are in the C. of E. School, I think Dr. Westgate should be called upon to see that they are removed. I have done everything I could in the matter. I have spoken to the authorities of the Provincial Government, and they led me to believe that they were going to have the children removed, but they will certainly keep them there as long as the Indian Department will allow it.

My own opinion is that the Department should issue explicit instructions to the Principals that they are not to admit these halfbreed children. On the 7th instant I wrote you in connection with a number of halfbreed children that had been admitted to the Qu'Appelle School by the Principal. If we relax our vigilance in this matter we will soon have our schools filled up with halfbreeds, as the information soon passes from one school to another.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Macdonald:

I called at the Office Friday P.M. as I promised you by post card which I sent in response to your note but found that you had been called away to Regina.

I understand that a protest in connection with Elizabeth Medicine Child being at the Onion Lake C.of E. School has been made by Father Lacombe.

The facts of the case, as I remember them, are these. Mr. Ellis came to the Reserve some two years ago, more or less, to see one or two people who had signified their intention to send children to his school. Naturally I went around with him. While I made a call at Sapoostayekun's he walked over to Medicine Child's and was back to Sapp's within four or five minutes to tell me that Mrs. Medicine Child was sending Elizabeth to Onion Lake. There was no time for conversation of a persuasive nature.

Later on Medicine Child came to see me and said he was glad Elizabeth was going to Onion Lake.

Mr. Ellis left the application form with me.

Now as regards the protest. The rule at the Onion Lake School is this. Parents write to the principal when they want their children to come home for the holidays. They send the money for the R.R. Fare of the child and if they have not got the money, they write any how. Elizabeth's fare would come to 85 cents, but Medicine Child did not even write to say he was at home and wanted Elizabeth to come home, much less send the small sum required for her fare. The only thing Mr. Ellis could do was to hold the girl pending word from the father.

Medicine Child was clearly at fault and yet this is the only reason he had for seeking to transfer Elizabeth. He told me so himself about three weeks ago! Mr. Ellis offended me for not sending Elizabeth back," he said, "that is the only reason I am taking the girl out of that school." He further stated that he did not press the point when he went to the office to see you but it was the priests who were so insistent (ka aylmesichik, who were fierce). He said that if the Dept. were not favorable to the transfer the girl would go back to Onion Lake.

Sir:

I have your 955-308A of the 12th instant, with reference to Elizabeth Medicinechild, pupil at the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School. I have discussed this case with the Rev. Mr. Ahenakew, and I am now satisfied that if all the facts had been known to the Department, this girl's admission would not have been approved. The application form shows her religion to be Anglican, but Mr. Ahenakew, who prepared the form, states that he left the space for religion blank. It would be interesting to know who wrote the word "Anglican" on the form.

The girl's father professes the Roman Catholic religion and the Rev. Mr. Ellis should not have considered admitting Elizabeth without laying the full facts before the Department. You will please so inform Mr. Ellis. For the purpose, I am enclosing a copy of this letter.

If any further protest is received, concerning this girl's presence in the Anglican School, you will please inform the Department forthwith. It is not the practice to transfer children from one Indian residential school to another for religious reasons, because this would lead to endless difficulty; but, if Medicinechild insists on withdrawing his child from the Anglican school, the Department will give favourable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 115-1-10 of the 21st instant advising me that the Rev. H. Ellis, Principal of the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School, reports that Samuel Brewer, No. 91, is absent from school without leave.

When children were returning to school after summer vacation Chief George Brewer wanted to trade a smaller child for Samuel who is sixteen years of age in order that he could stay at home in order to help with chores and so that a younger child was to take the place of Samuel at school. I informed the Chief then that it was no time to make such a proposition when the Principal was here in order to take children back to school, and that he would have to take the matter up with the Department as I had no authority to interfere with Boarding School regulations. The Chief would not allow Samuel to return with Mr. Ellis, claiming that the boy belonged to him and on account of old age and not feeling well he needed the boy at home in order to help make a living for the family. I may mention that Chief Brewer is in receipt of a double ration.

A month later when Mr. Ellis again returned in order to take some pupils back Inspector Hamilton was here and the Chief again refused to let his son return. I considered it better to write you fully in this connection giving you the Chief's viewpoint before calling upon the R.C.M.P. Police as I consider that some strong action will have to be taken in order to have this boy returned to school.

I will await your further instructions before proceeding further as yesterday I informed the Chief of your communication and he refused to comply with your instructions to allow the boy to return.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Under these circumstances, she was certainly not eligible for admission as a grant-earning pupil up to the time she went to live with Mrs. Quinney.

It is noted from your letter of the 12th ultimo that she only resided with Mrs. Quinney a few months before application was made for her admission to the Onion Lake School and the Department is inclined to feel that Mrs. Quinney took her simply for the purpose of having her placed in the school mentioned. Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your #115-I-IIQ of the 20th instant re application for admission of Gilbert Lazarus Sanderson to the Onion Lake C.E. Residential.

In reply I beg to say that when the child was born the mother was living with, (keeping house) for her brother Alex James Sanderson a member of the band who is separate from his wife.

Since her marriage to Descharmes, who has no home of his own, the mother has spent most of her time at her brothers home. In summer months Descharmes works for outsiders, when they live in a tent. When out of work and during the winter months they come back to her brother's home on the reserve.

I believe it can be said that the boy lived all his life on the reserve, and that he considers the reserve and his uncles home, his also. The uncle Alex James Sanderson has provided more for the boy than the foster-father has.

In my #4926-104-D.L. of the 16th instant I referred to Alex Descharmes as an outsider of Fort-a-la-Corne, P.O. This address may be misleading. Descharmes or Ducharme came from the Battleford district as a labourer looking for work. On July 9th 1924 shortly (some months) after his arrival, he was married to Isabella Sanderson by the Rev. R. McNamara, missionary in charge of the reserve. A daughter was born to them on April 28th 1925, this is the only child I know of.

I have the honour to be

The Secretary

Your obedient servant

Dear Mr. Turner,

In reply to your letter of Aug. 26, will you allow me to say that the expla-
nation you are giving me about Joe Littlewolf's ward does not alter my views in the matter.

I know that boy Philip Moona is not the son of Joe but his brother-in-law; that he is a catholic, that his sister Maria is a catholic, that two other sisters, Edna & Ida, as well as another brother are all catholic and brought up in our school at Delmas.

I have been told that the same Phillip was baptised a protestant on the day after his reception in the Anglican School, and so on the application for his admission there he could be labelled as a protestant.

Shortly after my arrival here in 1930, I had the visit of Littlewolf's wife, and she told me what I did not know at the time, that a brother of hers was at the neighbouring school, that she wanted to take him out and to have him admitted in my school. Then I refused to take any action and did not want any trouble with anybody, but this woman has come to me again and again, and with her husband. On July 15th last, they were again in my office, and besides the story I have related to you in my last letter of July 15th, they told me also that you have referred them to me to obtain the admission of the boy in the R.C. School, and that they do not want the boy to be brought up as a protestant.

Now in your letter of the 28th ultimo, you say that you are referring the matter to Ottawa, without any recommendation, but only stating the facts.

If you had all the particulars that I am giving you today, I would feel confident that it would be you that would alter views in the matter, and that the facts would have been presented by you to Ottawa in a different light.

All this is the result of a mistake made by the sister of Phillip Moona, mistake that has given you a wrong impression, kind of which you and I are not responsible. But these people want to amend their mistake; it remains that they are R.C., and they are anxious to have their ward educated as a R.C.

Now please take note that I did not go after these Littlewolfs, that they had come to me from their own volition, and even then I did not say anything against anybody, that I did not take the one way or other, although I think that in spite of their mistake they should get the satisfaction they are begging for. All I have said is that the solution of the difficulty is in the hands of Mr. Turner, Indian Agent, and I referred them to you, and I told them I would make application to you the way they wanted me.

Yours sincerely,
Portier Jos., Principal.

Dear Father Portier,

I have your letter of yesterday's date. Am sorry that I have not yet taken any action with respect to Philip Mooswa, other than to tell Joe Littlewolf to take the boy back to the Anglican school where he belongs. This boy, Philip, was placed in the Anglican school on November 5th, 1929, by Joe Littlewolf's wife, Maria, who signed the application for his admission, and the application was witnessed by her sister Ida Mooswa; the Mooswa family being described by them at that time, as Anglicans.

Your letter to me on this subject is dated July 16th, which happens to be the same date that I was forced to make my best look; which is one reason why action was taken at the time. Another reason is that as soon as I read the letter I noticed in it an incorrect and misleading statement, which was that "the boy being a Catholic and the charge of a Catholic family, should be at the R.C. School." This goes to show how a simple remark can be misconstrued.

The fact is this - last June when I was obtaining information from Joe for the Census, he mentioned to me that Philip was at the Anglican School, and remarked that it was queer that one boy should be there when all the rest of the family were R.C.; but at that time I was forgetting that Philip was not Joe's own boy, and thought that as soon as this was explained to you, you would alter your views in the matter.

I am today sending your letter of July 16th to the Department, with an explanation for the delay in forwarding it. I am making no recommendations in the matter, but am just stating the facts. In the meantime I would ask you to kindly use your influence to have Joe return Philip to the Anglican School. It was only the day before yesterday that I told Joe to take the boy back there, instead of doing so he went yesterday to see you in the matter.

Thank you very much for your good wishes respecting my health. It is much improved and I hope to be able to get to see you in the course of the next few days.

Yours sincerely,

Indian Agent.
Dear Sir,

The wife of Joe Wolf has come to see me several times about her little brother, and she begged me instantly to write you and the Department in order to get the transfer of that boy from the Anglican School to our school. Dear Sir:

In regards to my complaints about the Onion Lake School is as follows: Last October the third my boy went back to school in good health. Doctor Duncan examined the boy and he said the boy was in good health. My boy took sick soon after he got to the school and was in bed. We did not know anything about it till in December. We wrote to find out what was wrong with the boy. Mr. Ellis answered and said the boy was getting better and would be out of bed in a day or so. I went to see Mr. Weir and asked him if he would let my husband go, as I was not able to go myself. Mr. Weir said he could go as long as there was someone to do the work. Rev. Sir,

I would like to explain to you the position I have been obliged to take with respect to Philip Mooswa, as I do not want you to think I am prejudiced and looking for any unchristian & petty fight.

Shortly after I took charge of the R.C. Res. School here, I had the visit of Joe Littlewolf and wife; they told me that the boy Philip was in your school, but as they are all R. Cath., they wanted to have their ward in the R.C. School. I refused then to take any action since the boy has been admitted to your School on their own application. I told them that, if they had made any mistake, it was up to them to fix it and to see Mr. Turner about it.

Again and again they came to me, and during vacation timethey have been more insisting, and they went so far as quoting Mr. Turner as saying: "Since you are catholic, the boy should be at the R.C. School. So go and see Father Fortier who might be able to do something for you." On the strength of these words, and acting only as interpreter of Littlewolf and wife, I wrote to Mr. Turner, asking according to their wishes the transfer of the boy. Later on, I had to answer a communication of Mr. Turner, and to give what appear to be the reasons of the transfer, specially that the boy is a catholic, the ward of a catholic family, the brother of two girls and a boy all brought up in our R.C. School at Delmas.

So, you see, all I have done is to interpret & to act according to the wishes of the boy's real guardians, since the mother practically does not belong to any church as she is living irregularly with a married halfbreed, and practically also does not give any care and attention to her children.

I trust you will judge I have been fair in the part I have taken in that case.

We are neighbour and both working for what we believe is a good cause, and I do not wish anything better than a friendly feeling between us, and a good & helpful understanding.

I trust, therefore, that our relationship with each other will be such that we do not hinder that work by anything that would appear to be unseemly or unchristian. More prominence should be given to the wishes of the deceased father and those of the foster father, who has looked after Phillip for some years. I believe that the civil courts of the province would regard his wishes. He requests an education under Roman Catholic auspices and, as this is the religion of the home to which Phillip will return, the Department believes that it is in his best interests to be placed in the Onion Lake R. C. Residential School.

I know that you are interested in the future welfare of this boy and it is felt that a careful review of the different angles of this case (as outlined in both this and my former letter), will lead you to reconsider the decision conveyed in your recent letter.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of October 17th, and your reply to the same on October 29th, 115-1-10, re the above-mentioned pupil, I beg to state that after a very careful study of all the communications I have received in this connection, I am strongly of the opinion that he should be returned to our Society's School at Onion Lake. I have before me a copy of the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of June 5th, 1922, addressed to our General Secretary, and would direct your attention to the closing paragraphs of the same which read as follows:

"As intimated in my earlier communication in this connection, I do not wish this ruling to be the occasion of requests that children be transferred from one school to another on the grounds of the present decision. I believe that a child, that has been resident in a school and may have imbibed religious opinions, should remain in that school for the full tuition period.

The Department enlists your sympathetic cooperation in the event of difficult cases for decision in the future."

The ruling and wishes of your Department as set forth in that letter have received from our Society the most careful and sympathetic consideration ever since it came to hand, and will continue to do so until the specific rulings therein laid down have been finally altered. It seems to me, however, that your approval of the transfer of the pupil in question from our Onion Lake School to the R.C. School presided over by Father Fortier is a direct departure from the opinion expressed by the Deputy Superintendent.
General, namely "that a child that has been resident in a school, and may have imbibed religious opinions, should remain in that school for the full tuition period." Philip Mooswa was in residence in our Onion Lake School for two years. I have before me an affidavit signed and witnessed, that the father and mother and family were Anglicans. I have before me also a letter from our Missionary, the Rev. Edward Ahenakew, who is himself a Cree Indian, in which he states that he and the Principal of our Onion Lake School drove 160 miles to interview Mrs. Mooswa who is now married to a half-breed named Cardinal, and in this letter he states that Mrs. Mooswa herself told him that she was glad the boy was placed in the Anglican School.

For these reasons, and others, which I do not consider it necessary now to mention, I am forced to the conclusion that the admission of this pupil to the R.C. School should never have been allowed, and I consider it only fair to our Society, and to the management of our Onion Lake School, that his transfer to our School be effected immediately, all expense in connection with the same being met by your Department.

CONFIDENTIAL

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter (marked confidential) of the 11th instant, number 115-1-10, dealing with the question of the transfer of the above mentioned pupil from our Onion Lake School, to the Roman Catholic School on that Reserve. After a very careful review of all the correspondence and documents which have reached me in connection with this matter, I find it very difficult to alter the request set forth in my letter to you on Nov. 23rd, 1931, as I am still convinced that Father Fortier, the Principal of the Roman Catholic Onion Lake School, should not have allowed this pupil to enter his School, when he knew that he was born of Anglican parents and had actually been in residence for two years at our Society's School. The Indian Agent's statement that "the Mooswe family have all been recognized as Roman Catholic" does not harmonize with a certified statement, duly witnessed, which I have received from one, John Muskego, who writes as follows:

"I, Johnny Muskego, Treaty Indian, living on the Onion Lake Reserve, do certify that I knew Mooswe who lived near my house, and that I knew him to be an Anglican with his wife and family".

This certified statement is dated Onion Lake, 7th November, 1931.

When the father died, and the mother left the Reserve because of Mr. Indian agent Macdonald's attitude towards her, (see letter of Rev. Principal Ellis to you, Nov. 5th, 1931) this boy was taken care of by her sister, who also was an Anglican, and remained an Anglican until she married a Roman
Catholic named Littlewolf. It was she who placed the boy Philip in our Society's School, and no question was ever raised about his transfer to the Roman Catholic School for two years, or until after she herself had been received into the Roman Catholic Church.

As I understand that you have received a copy of the letter of the Rev. Father Fortier, Principal of the Roman Catholic School at Union Lake, and addressed to Mr. Principal Ellis of our Society's School, I need not repeat the information therein set forth with regard to the part he took in the matter, except to point out that in answering the communication he had received from Mr. Indian Agent Turner, he gave the following information, which, so far as I can make out, is not true to fact:

(1) that the boy is Catholic, (I presume he means Roman Catholic). My understanding is that the father and mother of this boy, and the boy himself, were all baptized members of the Church of England.

(2) that the boy was the ward of a Catholic family. My understanding is that when this boy was placed in our Society's School, and was registered under the number 146, he came under the official guardianship of the Principal of that School, a guardianship which cannot be cancelled without the united consent of your Department and the Principal himself.

(3) that he was the brother of two girls and a boy, all brought up in the Roman Catholic School at Delmas. My understanding is that the two girls referred to are Maria and Eliza Muskego, (I have no information about the boy mentioned) who have been in residence for some time at the Roman Catholic School at Delmas, and should never have been admitted to that institution, as your Department was furnished with the dates when these children were baptized in the Anglican Church, the father himself being present at the service (see letter of the Rev. Principal Ellis to your Department, March 15th, 1932). Official protests were made against the admission of these Anglican children to a school under Roman Catholic administration, but the protests were non-effective. I have before me a statement from the father in which he declares that these children were taken into the Roman Catholic School without his consent, and while they were living with his father during his absence. As the boy Philip Mooswa was placed in our Society's School by his aunt, and with the full consent of his mother (see my letter of Nov. 23rd, 1931), and remained there until the aunt was received into the Roman Church when she married the Roman Catholic Littlewolf, it seems to me that he should have been allowed to remain there, and that he would have remained there had it not been for the united efforts of Father Fortier and Littlewolf and his wife, to take him away.
As you ask for my sympathetic cooperation in the settlement of this difficult case, I can only say that although I can see no valid reason whatever why this pupil should be transferred, after two years of residence, from our School to a Roman Catholic School, I am content to leave the matter in your Department's hands and to abide by the ruling laid down in the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of June 5th, 1922, addressed to our General Secretary, and which reads, in part, as follows:

"The Department reserves the right to make decisions in special cases that are brought to our attention".

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

October 6th, 1932

With reference to the above, on this date Dr. J.T. Hill, Indian Agent of Union Lake, Sask., handed me a list of the names of Indian children who were not attending school at the missions, and requested me to interview the parents of these children and instruct them to send their children to school.

This same date I patrolled per saddle horse reg. No. 2030, to Union Lake District North, east & south and interviewed eight of these families and questioned them as to why their children were not attending school, and in most of the cases I learned that the children had been kept at home as the parents were sick, but they all promised to take their children back to school as soon as possible. I was unable to locate one family named Lewis, as they were treasuring somewhere in Frenchman's Butte District, but I left word for the parents, who were expected to return at the end of the week, to send their children to school.

I returned to Union Lake in the P.M. of this date per saddle horse, reg. No. 2030.

Dear Dr. Hill:

I herewith ask the Department to admit and allow Bella Patemude, age 7 years to become a grant earning pupil in the C. E. Indian Residential School on the grounds of her being desitute and has no responsible person to take care of her.

It appears when the father died, the child was adopted by the grandmother (a treaty Indian) as the mother married again and did not want the child. When the grandmother died, the child was given to Josephine, an aunt, on the understanding that when the child reached the age of 7 years, she would place the child in school. This promise has now been carried out. The aunt states that she cannot look after this child herself as she has a family of her own and is in very poor circumstances herself.

As the mother of this child is in treaty, I would suggest that the Department admit this child also and approve of the said child taking up her residence here in our school.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following regarding Bella Patnaude (breed) age 7 or 8 years, whose guardian, Mrs. Josephine Patnaude, and mother, Margaret Patnaude, desire her to enter an Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. The former signed an admission form for her to enter the C. of E. Indian Residential School, while the latter signed a similar one for admission to the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School.

Bella Patnaude is the daughter of Margaret Patnaude (treaty Indian) and “Jim” Patnaude (deceased breed). The Principal of each school have applied for her admission to their church claiming that she was baptized into his church. The information I have in this connection is that she was baptized by the late Father Dupre in infancy, and by the Reverend H. Ellis, Principal of the Anglican School, about two years ago. It is quite apparent that this girl was adopted by her grandmother when her father died, and later when the grandmother died, she was placed with an aunt with instructions that she was to be placed in school when she reached the age of seven. The parents in this case were both Roman Catholics and the grandmother was buried by a priest. Mr. Ellis stated that the grandmother was received into his church.

At present both schools are over strength as the returns will show, and have been for some time. I am enclosing the two admission forms uncompleted and unsigned for the Department’s information.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your 99-18 of the 5th instant, with reference to a request received for the admission of Bella Patnaude to an Indian residential school. The information contained in your letter has been carefully noted. The Department is inclined to feel that, if this girl is admitted to any school, she should be placed in one conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

However, it is noted, from the last paragraph of your letter, that both the Onion Lake C.E. and the Onion Lake R.C. Residential Schools have their full quota of pupils, and the Department is not prepared to consider admitting this girl to either school at the present time.

Sir,

2-10-33

1. With reference to the above, in the P.M. of this date I was informed by Rev. Ellis of the above mentioned mission that the above named disappeared from the mission about noon and had not returned, and wished me to endeavour and locate him.

2. This same date I patrolled per Auto Livery; no Police Transport being available, to the Sheridan Ferry and made enquiries there as to whether the child had crossed there that day, and was informed that no Indian child had crossed there. I then returned to Onion Lake with the intention of patrolling to Hewitt's Landing ferry, and in the meantime telephoned to Rev. Ellis with a view of further discussing this matter with him, and he informed me that the above named had returned to the mission about half hour previous to this.

Dear Sir,

I have just heard that the admission of Maria Anne Fox, daughter of Edouard Fox has been approved by the Department for the C.E. Res. School, and it is quite a surprise.

Edouard Fox, who has always been a Rom. Cath., and his daughter was baptised in the same church on the 6th of May 1925, so far as I know, has never been baptised in any other church. That same Edouard Fox came to my office, and applied for the admission of his daughter in the R.C. Res. School; the form was filled up before witness and properly signed. Moreover he told me that he never signed any other application and never gave his consent for the admission of his daughter in any other school.

For your edification, I would like to give you the history of his marriage, history which he told me himself. It was in the year 1925, Edouard Fox was visiting at the protestant School with five or six of his friends. It was known that he was anxious to marry a girl, ex-pupil of that School. He was invited to come in and visit the chapel; he went in and was surprised to find there his girl and also the minister. This gentleman asked him if he thought he wanted to marry "this girl", and he answered affirmatively; the reciprocal question being made to the girl, they were told to be married. "Of course," he said to me, "I did not believe in that marriage, and I did not consider myself tied up by such, so much so that I did not take the girl with me until three months after the girl turned to be a Rom. Cath. like myself, was baptised by Father Therien and were really married by the same priest."

From that marriage are two children: the girl mentioned above, and a boy; both have been baptised in the R.C. Church.

Now here is what happened just last week: The wife of Edouard Fox, dangerously sick, asked and begged twice, of her volition, for the Cath. priest; they sent for the priest. The last time was saturday at 5 a.m., the sick woman saying that she wanted to see the priest once more before her death.

But I trust that is plenty enough to convince you there is something wrong somewhere, and I beg you to reconsider the approbation you have given. I may tell you that with you I dislike such controversy, and many times I have refrained to make complaint and to bother you, even when I thought I had good reasons for it. In the mean time I take pleasure to say that in dealing with the Department I have generally received fair treatment, and I am sincerely thankful for that.

Yours truly

Rev. Joe. Portier, Principal
