Re-admission of Maria Anne Fox.

Dear Sir, I had today the visit of Edward Fox and his wife, and these are the declarations they made:

Both are R. Catholic; the man has always been so, the wife who once was anglican has joined the Cath. Church eight or nine years ago and was baptised in that Church. Their daughter has also been christened R. Catholic.

Edward has not signed any application for the C.E. School, and if his name appeared in such application it has been given by his father-in-law. But he has given his name before witness for the R.C. School.

Lately the wife, dangerously sick and giving all hope of recovery has confided the care of her daughter to her parents who are protestants. They said that the C.E. minister came often to their place, several times accompanied by the Indian Agent and by a councillor of the Reserve.

Still both are declaring they belong to the Cath. Church and will continue to stick to that Church.

It is clearly evident that they would like to bring up their children in their Church, that is in the Cath. Church, but they are afraid of the parents of the wife, of the Indian Agent and of the C.E. minister: That is my impression and what they have clearly expressed.

I trust that you will judge that a cath. child born of cath. parents has to go to a cath. School, according to the rule of the Department.

Once more I want to say that I dislike such trouble and controversy, but certainly I did not start it, neither look for it.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Portier, Principal  
Onion Lake R.C. Ind. Res. School.
Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-1-10, of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the admission of Maria Anne Fox to the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian residential School, and in reply.

I based my recommendation on the information available at the time the application was forwarded to the Department. Briefly, it was as follows: Edward Fox, R. C., was married to Agnes Waskahat, an ex-pupil of the Anglican School, on June 17th, 1925. The ceremony took place in the Anglican church, Onion Lake, Rev. J. T. Ellis, at Fox's request, officiated. The bride's father and mother witnessed the marriage and signed the register. Fox accepted the Protestant faith on that occasion and has been a consistent Anglican ever since. The applicant, Maria Anne (their first child) was baptized in infancy by Rev. Canon Ahenekeew. Fox, whom I interviewed again today, stated most emphatically that he was a Protestant and had been since his marriage. He signed the application form for the admission of his daughter into the C. of E. School, but did not sign any other.

Re Rev. Father Portier's statements. There is an entry of the baptism of Maria Anne, on May 6, 1926, in the R. C. records. It is quite correct that Mrs. Fox, who was sick, had asked for the priest, meaning the Anglican priest. The message went to the Catholic priest and he responded. The Rev. Ellis was sent for immediately after, and attended the sick woman. The remaining statements in Rev. Fox's letter are undoubtedly what Fox told him. Fox denies this, but he is not reliable. It is quite common for the Indian children of mixed marriages to be baptized into both churches, and this apparently happened in this case.

E. Fox, No. 0163, is from Sweet Grass reserve, Battleford Agency, and is not related to Maria Anne. I am still of the opinion that the application I signed for the admission of Maria Anne Fox into the C. of E. School was correct and proper.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

J. T. Ellis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of Feb. 13, (No. 115-1-10) referring to the admission of Maria Anne Fox to the C.E. High School, I am sorry to say that I can hardly digest the statements sent to you by Mr. Agent Hill, and even I will venture to say that I am rather surprised of the position he has taken in the whole matter. Very likely he has been fooled and deceived, and I may have been too. But how is it that one day last fall Mr. Hill came to me and said: "Say, I have received from the C.E. School an application for the admission to that school of the daughter of E. Fox." "What! replied, that is not right; the girl is catholic, and Fox has repeatedly here promised to give us his daughter." "Well," he said, "I am giving you a hint."

Mr. Hill said in his letter to you that Fox denies the statements I have sent to the Department, but the same Fox has also with me denied all the statements made by Mr. Hill or any other. Where is the truth?

Will you kindly let me again expose briefly the particulars of the case? Here it is:

Edward Fox has always been a Catholic, and still claims that he is so, and has never accepted the protestant faith. In 1925, he was visiting at the protestant school with five or six of his friends; it was known that he was anxious to marry a girl, ex-pupil of that school. He was invited to come in and see the chapel; he went in and was surprised to find inside there his girl and the minister. This minister asked him if it was true that he wanted to marry "this girl", and of course he answered affirmatively; the record-book question being inside of the girl, they were declared to be united. I cannot understand why, it was told me by Fox himself; so it does not look that it was at Fox' request that such marriage ceremony took place. Moreover, he told me that he did not believe in that kind of ceremony, and did not consider tied up by such, and he did not take the girl with him till after three or four months the girl joined the Oath Church, was baptized by Father Therien and both were properly married by the same priest.

Here are the extracts of baptism and marriage:

"On the 4th day of Oct. 1925, we undersigned priest, after the publication of the banns of marriage made in the R.C. Church between Edward Fox, son of age of J.B. Fox on the one part, and Aldina Marie Waskahat, minor daughter of Joe Waskahat on the other part, we have received their mutual consent, and have solemnly united them in the sacred bonds of matrimony. Then, during the celebration of Holy Mass, we have given them the nuptial benediction in the presence of the witnesses: Jos Opesinaw and Isabelle Opesinaw.

(sgn); J.A. Therien O.M.I."

"Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6323, file 658-10, part 5)

The daughter, Maria Anne, was born of this marriage on the 3rd May 1926, and here is the extract of her baptism:

"On the 6th of May 1926, we undersigned priest have solemnly baptized Maria Anne, born in legitimate wedlock from Edward Fox and Marie Aldina Waskahat. The godfather has been Antoine Wolf and the godmother Mary Wolf.

(sgn): J.E. Teston O.M.I."

Now in contradiction with what says Mr. Agent Hill that Fox is a protestant since his marriage by the Rev. Ellis, Fox states most emphatically that he is a catholic. When his wife was sick, the catholic priest was sent for, and there was no mistake, or the same mistake have been made twice on the same week. The wife told me that Mr. Ellis called at their place later on, but that she did not need him since she already had the administration of the catholic priest. Moreover, after her recovery, that woman came here with her husband; both received the sacraments in my church. I don't suppose that for such public and open demonstration of their faith they were taking my church by mistake for the C.E. church. And after that, the same day (last 3rd or 4th of febr.) they came in my office and told me again that their faith was the R.C. faith, the wife speaking that way even more lengthily than the man.

For the application form Fox denies that he has signed none for the admission of his daughter to the C.E. School, and he certainly gave his name for the admission to the R.C. School and did it in my presence and in the presence of another witness.

May I add some little details that have some importance? Edward Fox has never been to school, so speaks and understands very little English, and I do speak and understand cree, i.e. his language, and I have no clerk or secretary to write my letters, I do that myself and I do it without any prejudice, if not (I beg your pardon) very grammatically.

That is the last letter I am writing to you on the above occasion, and by the way on any other matter of Indian Affairs, since I am leaving this week the principalship of the Onion Lake R.C. School. I am indeed very sorry that such painful controversy had arisen just before my departure. I have always tried to be true, fair in all my dealings with the Department, to be polite and considerate with anyone connected with this Department. But I want earnestly to thank you personally for the very appreciated, gentle, kind manner you have always treated.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Joe Portier
Principal (for two more days)

Re te Mr. Edward Fox & Child.

Both Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fox are here again this evening, to say that they desire to have their girl admitted in the R.C. School, being Catholics they want their children to be of the same creed.

Mr. Edward Fox now admits that he did sign the admission of his girl for both schools, but he added, "If I did sign for the C.E. School, it was through vexation, I was continually harassed by my father-in-law, Joe Waskahat to send my daughter to the C.E. School."

Both Mr. and Mrs. E. Fox state that on one occasion, at table a discussion on the child's schooling arose. Mr. J. Waskahat was most imperative in his wish to send the girl to the C.E. school but Mr. Fox refused to comply with his request, when the dispute was at its hottest, Edward left the room saying, "Place the child wherever you wish," this he said, to get rid of the row and have peace. Mrs. Fox, for her part did not want to grieve her parents in going against their wishes so she suggested that the girl should be given to the grandparents. Later she sought the Agent's advice on the matter. Mr. Cameron who was present objected, saying that both father and mother being alive, it was impossible to do so.

Some time after the fact mentioned, Mr. J. Waskahat drove up, he was accompanied by J. Heathen, accountant, both Waskahat and Heathen pressed on Mr. E. Fox to sign the admission of his daughter into the Anglican school, they drove him up to the school and there disregarding his determination not to send the girl to school, Edward signed the admission in order to free himself from his harassing relatives, for he was in no hurry to send his daughter, he declared.

Later, said he, "I met the Indian Agent who inquired where I intended to send my boy, I replied, I do not want to be bothered with the question, but if ever I decide to send him to school I'll send him wherever I please." My wife added, "It is alright for him to be a Roman Catholic, is this the Indian Agent replied, "See here, I do not favour one school more than the other, I simply want these children where they belong, any way, by the time you will be ready to send your boy to school, I'll perhaps not be an Indian Agent then."

Both the Indian Agent and Mr. Ellis are notified that the boy will be placed in the R.C. School.
Re to the baptism of Marie Ann, my first born. It is a fact that the child was baptized in the R.C. Church two days after her birth, the mother herself took the baby to church, accompanied by the godmother, Mrs. Joe Little Wolf, who is here present. This took place the 16th of May 1936. Later when the child was over a year old, Rev. Aheneckew rebaptized her. It happened thus, Rev. Aheneckew was at Onion Lake, he was leaving for Lloyminster, with Mr. Joe Waskahat, the latter sent his daughter to see Mr. Aheneckew, she did so, and Mr. Aheneckew asked Mrs. E. Fox to baptize her baby; he offered a blanket in return, she accepted.

As a proof that they adhere to the R.C. Church, seven children born from their union, were baptized in the R.C. Church and five of these were attended by the R.C. priest at their burial.

Re: Truant Indian Girls-Anglican Mission,
Onion Lake, Sask.

8-10-34.

Headquarters

With reference to the above, in the A.M. of this date I received a telephone message from Rev. H. Ellis of the above mentioned Mission informing me that two Indian girls, namely Maggie ARNOLD (16 years old) and Edith MURDOCK (17 years old) had disappeared from the Mission on the afternoon of the 7th inst., and that he and the staff had been unable to locate them, and requested me to investigate the matter.

Sub-Division

I immediately patrolled per Pte.Auto to the home of John MURDOCK, father of one of the girls, and he informed me that neither of the girls had come there, and he was of the opinion that they may have gone towards Frenchman's Butte, enroute to LITTLE Lake Reserve. I then patrolled to Harlan, P.C. Pratt and Frenchman's Butte District, making enquiries enroute, but was unable to find any trace of these girls. I then returned to Onion Lake and to District North and to the home of Mrs. Pratt, Grandmother of Edith MURDOCK, but Edith had not come there. I then returned to Onion Lake, where I learned that the two girls in question had stayed the previous night at the home of Mr. Dufrene, near the border of the Reserve, and that they had left there in the morning at daylight, ostensibly heading for Frog Lake Reserve. I then patrolled to Frog Lake making enquiries enroute, and learned from the Indians of Frog Lake Reserve that the girls had not been seen there. I then returned to Onion Lake in the late P.M. of this date.

9-10-34.

In the A.M. I patrolled per Pte.Auto to Onion Lake Reserve and made further enquiries in this connection, but was unable to obtain any further information. In the P.M. of this date I patrolled from Harlan District, off other Police duties, to Onion Lake Reserve, and interviewed an Old timer named MILLER who informed me that he had seen the girls had been seen in that vicinity about noon that day, and that they might be found at the home of Edward FOX on the South side of the Reserve. I then patrolled to the home of Fox and found both girls hiding in an old building near Fox's place. I escorted both girls to the Anglican Mission this date, and then returned to Onion Lake.

Both these girls had hidden in the brush on the Reserve, on Sunday afternoon until 2 A.M. Monday morning when they went to Dufrene's place, and all day Monday and that night until noon Tuesday, and had lived on berries.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill,

His Grace Bishop Prud'homme cites the following from a letter received from Mrs. Cook:

"Reverend Father Pratt told me that he has put you in touch with the question of the Cook children who are at the Church of England School at Onion Lake.

I came to beg of your paternal kindness to favour us with your cooperation in trying to secure a transfer for the above children to the R.C. school of Onion Lake. It is a fact that my eldest daughter has been placed in the Anglican school some seven years ago and later my son was also admitted in the same school.

My husband has been for a time negligent catholic and it was during this period that the children were sent to the Anglican School. Mr. Cook has now come back to better sentiments towards his church and wants to be a better catholic, consequently he wants his children in a catholic school. We have kept the children home this year, up to the present time, but we were ordered by the Indian agent to send them back to the Anglican school and it was in spite of our will that the order was executed yesterday."

Will you kindly obtain an immediate report for the information of the Minister.

George Bushard
Private Secretary.

Per:
January 7th, 1935.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable The Superintendent General,

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 4th instant, with reference to a letter received from His Grace Bishop Prud'homme regarding the children of Mrs. Cook.

On reviewing the quarterly returns of the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School, I can only find two children by the name of "Cook". One child, Catherine Cook, was admitted to the Onion Lake C. E. Residential School in May, 1930; the other, Edwin Cook, was admitted to the same school in February, 1934. The application forms are signed by the father, Sam Cook, and I presume that these are the children to whom Bishop Prud'homme refers. In each case, the application forms, which have been approved by the Indian Agent, state that the religion is "Anglican".

There is nothing on file to indicate that incorrect information regarding the religious belief of the children was given to the Department at the time of their admission to the Onion Lake C. E. School.

When a child has once been admitted to a residential school, it has not been the practice of the Department in the past to transfer such child to another residential school for religious reasons.

Deputy Superintendent General.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub-Division Detachment
No. 7 North Battleford, Onion Lake Detachment.

Province Date
Saskatchewan September 23rd, 1935.

Fyle References
Re: Catherine & Mein Cook (Indians) - Truant School Children.
Onion Lake Reserve, Saskatchewan.

Headquarters
21-9-35.
1. With reference to the above, in the late afternoon of this date,
Rev. Ellis, Principal of the Anglican Mission, Onion Lake Reserve,
communicated with this Detachment, and stated that he had endeavored
to get the above named children to attend school since it had opened
this fall, but had not been able to do so. He requested that I make
the necessary patrol on the following day, to get these children, and
then take them to school. These children are registered at this
school, having attended prior to the Summer Holidays.

Sub-Division
22-9-35.
2. In the early morning of this date, I patrolled per #6 Auto to
the house of Sam Cook, father of these two children, and on arrival
found that the children had been waiting for me, and run away into
the brush, as soon as I appeared. I questioned Cook about his children
not returning to school, but he was unable to understand English and I
found it necessary to get an Interpreter. Cook has apparently had a
misunderstanding with Mr. Ellis, and consequently had not sent his
children back to school. However when it was explained to him that the
children had to attend, he helped search for them; the boy as the girl
had returned by this time.

3. As the boy could not be found, it was decided that we take the
girl to school, and then search for the boy afterwards. This was done.
4. No trace could be found of the boy, so I returned to the
detachment where I remained until further orders.

5. At 9:00 p.m., I again patrolled to the house of Sam Cook, and on
arrival found that the boy had returned. Sam Cook handed him over to
me. I took him to the Mission, there handed him over to the Principal.
Returned to the Detachment at Midnight.

P.C.R.

Dear Sir:

Again I come to you, to ask you if it will be possible to have my boy transfer from the Anglican School to the R.C. Residential School. I have there two children which have admitted before and the girl who has only one more year to go can stay there, but the boy who has few years more to go to school I would like to have him transfer to the R.C. School.

In fact, you state that being before the Dept. officially known as an Anglican I was never baptised in that religion and was drawn to follow Anglican Religion only because I had been promised many things. My knowledge at that time, of the religion was very limited, and through ignorance I made that mistake to let my children go to learn a religion in a school not of my own creed. It was really a mistake and I regret it.

When writing to you again today, may I say that no one had exercised influence on me but I do it according to the dictation of my conscience.

Therefore, I will greatly appreciate, if your answer be favorable to my request.

I am, Sir

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith, Certificate of Health, and Application for Admission to the Onion Lake Anglican Indian Residential School for Lawrence Gilbert Buck, age 12 years.

This boy is the son of Lydia Cardinal, formerly No.155, Wm. Twatta Band, Carleton Agency, by her husband Richard Gilbert Buck, a non treaty Indian halfbreed.

The woman commuted her annuity under authority of Department letter No.25-107, dated September 21st, 1932.

This couple separated some years ago. I am told that she is living with another man on the outskirts of the City of Prince Albert. The husband, Buck has no home and works at odd jobs for farmers and others. He is an addict to liquor, and has been picked up several times by the police for being drunk.

After the parents separated the boy made his home with his paternal grandparents, Arthur Buck and his wife, old destitute Indian halfbreeds who were receiving old age pension, and lived in a borrowed shack on the outskirts of Prince Albert City. The grandfather died in August 1935, after which the old blind helpless grandmother and the boy went to live with her sister widow Mrs. Whitehead, No.40, on James Smith's Reserve.

Last year I asked Mrs. McFarlane, teacher at Fort la Corne North Indian Day School to take him into her school. After a few months his attendance became irregular, and he would turn up at all hours of the day or night at different Indians homes on the reserve.

This boy born of a treaty indian woman has no home other than with the Whiteheads, his relatives on the James Smith's Reserve. His parents lead miserable lives and cannot care for him, moreover I would not take the responsibility of sending him back to his mother to live with her under present conditions. He is a bright intelligent little fellow and four years in one of our schools would do him a great deal of good. I therefore strongly recommend that his admission be approved. He is at present at the school having been taken there by the Rev. Mr. E. Ellis when he came to James Smith's Reserve for the other pupils.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Edwin COOK & Johnny BIRD (Indians) - Escaped from Anglican Mission
Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Sask.

16-10-36.

(1). With reference to the above, in the a.m. of this date, a telephone message was received from Dr. J.C. Hill, Indian Agent stating that the above named boys had run away from the Anglican Mission. He requested that a search be made for these boys, and when located that they be taken back to school.

(2). Accordingly this same p.m. patrol was made per pte. auto to the Reserve east and south and return for the purpose of finding the boys. We learned that they had been seen at the house of an old Indian by the name of Fox on the previous night, and that they had hidden in the brush. The parents had not seen Edwin, as they were also helping to search for him. Johnny BIRD was from another reserve, so his parents were not interviewed.

(3). After making numerous enquiries from Indians on the reserve and also searching the bush it was decided that there was little possibility of finding these boys until night, when they would turn up somewhere for food, and so I returned to the Detachment. Various Indians were asked to keep the boys and report immediately if any trace was found of them.

(4). The above search was conducted in co-operation with members of the Anglican Mission Staff.

17-10-36.

(5). In the a.m. of this date, patrol was again made with the pte. auto to the Reserve east to make further enquiries. The Mission Staff called at the home of Edwin COOK, and arrested Johnny BIRD, but were unable to locate Edwin COOK.

(6). The parents of this boy were again interviewed by me, and requested to assist with the search, and if they were successful to take the boy back to the Mission. I returned to Detachment.

18-10-36.

(7). This date, the parents of Edwin COOK were successful in locating and returning Edwin to the Mission.

(8). Copy of this report sent direct to the Onion Lake Agency.

Sergeant SHOW OF P., Oct. 16th. to 31st, 1936.

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-1-10, of the 3rd ultimo, with reference to the admission of Morris Fox into the C. of E. Indian Residential School.

I recommend the admission after conferring with the Reverend Father Pratt and telling him that I had received an application signed by the boy's father for his admission into the C. of E. School, and Father Pratt assuring me that he would not contest it. My object in interviewing Father Pratt was to avoid a repetition of what occurred in 1935 when this boy's sister, Marie Anne Fox, No. 0167, was officially admitted into the C. of E. School on November 8th.

May I refer the Department to my replies to their letters 115-1-10, of Jan. 26, 1934, and 115-1-10, of Feb. 27, 1934, which deal quite fully with the religion of Fox and his wife in 1933. There has been no change since and the situation is practically identical. Father Pratt when confronted with what I consider a change of attitude repeated he would neither fight nor contest the admission but considered it his duty to put in a formal protest.

Mr. Ellis, principal of the C. of E. School, has been notified that Morris Fox' admission is cancelled.

There is no Arsene Fox. This was a clerical error on the part of Father Pratt.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:—

Re.: I15-I-IO...Re M. Fox

Yours of the 12 inst. received and excuse the delay in answering it.

Dr. J.T. Hill, our local Indian Agent is perfectly right when stating that I answered him I will not fight the case but only put in a formal protest.

I had in mind that he understood what that would mean, after the fight for the first child being admitted to the other school and also after the facts were well known.

Certainly I was surprised when the question was asked me "If I was going to fight the present case."

Certainly in presence of the actual situation my only mean left in my power was to answer "I will only protest formally" and it is why I sent to the Dept. the letter concerning the Fox boy.

I still maintain strongly my protest and the Dept. may be sure that nothing else will be done. I repeat also that Ed. Fox is a catholic and is known by every member of this Reserve as so.

Also, when our Indian Agent, asked a second time about the Fox's child I told him exactly the very same thing and I never had and will never have a change of attitude in this question and my duty is to maintain the formal protest put in.

This M. Fox had been in my school over more than two months a year or so ago, I made a Regular and Official Formal Application for Admission and nothing was heard of.

In Justice Dr. Hill, our Indian Agent, is not to be blamed for the present situation and the reasons causing such frictions are outside his jurisdiction and power and I feel not to mention the reasons which made Ed. Fox changing his mind.

I am pleased to say that when I had applied to the Dept. for a what I consider justice, I had always received the most appreciated consideration and decision.

I am always resolved to follow exactly all the Regulations of the Indian Dept. regarding the Indian Boarding schools.

Hoping sincerely that this letter will be received with the very same spirit with which she has been written and not to hurt or knock down anyone. Whatever your decision will be, she will be accepted as the Dept. decision.

Yours very truly

Dear Sir:-

Re Morris Fox, son of Edward and Mary Fox,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Rev. H. Ellis, Principal of our Society's School at Onion Lake, writing on the 4th inst., informs me that he received word on Nov. 4th last that the admission of the above mentioned Indian boy had been approved by your Department.

He also states that a few days later he received a telephone message from the local Indian Agent informing him that your Department had cancelled the approval previously given, and stating that the boy's name should not appear on the returns for the December Quarter. Why the cancellation order was given is not fully clear to the Principal of our School, but it would appear that some communication or other was sent to your Department by the Principal of the Roman Catholic School at Onion Lake. The facts of the case as they have been presented to me are as follows: Agnes Fox, mother of Morris Fox, is a graduate of our Society's School; Edward Fox, father of this boy, is a graduate of the Roman Catholic School.

When they were married the ceremony was conducted by the Rev. Principal of our Society's School, and the children were baptized by him. In 1933 one of their children—a girl—was admitted to our School, and is, I believe, still there.

When the father was informed that your Department had refused to admit his boy Morris to our School he asked the Rev. Principal Ellis to admit him to membership in the Church of England. He was duly admitted, and I understand that another application has now been sent to your Department.
requesting the admission of the boy Morris to our Society's School. If the facts of the case are as they have been presented to me, and as I have set them forth above, then I can see no reason whatever why this boy should not be admitted immediately to our School. The Rev. Principal Ellis informs me that no attempt was ever made by him to persuade Edward Fox to join our Church. It is my understanding, therefore, that this Indian sought admission to the Church of England of his own free will, and consequently his wishes with regard to the education of his son should be respected.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Ottawa, March 17th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

Last October, the Department received from Indian Agent Hill an application form for the admission of Morris Fox, son of Edward Fox, #124 Onion Lake Band, to the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School. As the application form stated that the religion of the boy was Anglican and was approved by the Indian Agent, the admission was approved. Later, Reverend Father Pratt, Principal of the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School, wrote the Department protesting against the boy's admission to the Onion Lake C. E. School on the grounds that the Fox family are Catholics.

On the occasion of your next visit to the Onion Lake Agency, please interview all parties concerned and, after you have made your investigation, you should let us know the results, with a view to assisting us to determine under what religious auspices this boy should be educated.

You will note sub-section 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act. The intention of this section is that an Indian child should attend a school conducted under the auspices of the church with which the child and its parents are affiliated. The Department believes that strict adherence to this rule is in the best interests of its wards. Whenever any disagreement arises regarding the religious auspices under which a child should be educated, we endeavour to ascertain the religion of the parents and the real wish of the father at the time application is made for the admission of the child to a residential school.

In the case under discussion, there is disagreement regarding the religious auspices under which the child should be educated and, as mentioned above, the Department desires you to fully investigate the matter and report.

Yours truly,

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

T. H. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith you will find an application from Eva Vandal, of the Sandy Lake Reserve, for admission to the Residential School for Indians at Onion Lake.

Duck Lake, Sask., November 2nd, 1937

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgement receipt of your letter dated the 4th ultimo, and which was received on the 12th, asking that Jessie Burns be re-admitted to your School.

While visiting the James Smith's Reserve on the 28th ult. I took this matter up with her father Angus Burns, who stated that you had taken this girl back to Onion Lake with her brother Mike, and he felt she should have been left at home to go to the Day School which she has been attending since January 1935.

I feel that where School children have good homes and are in easy reach of the Day School, such as this girl's case, they should attend the Schools on the Reserve. By so doing we could accommodate the orphans and those living in homes not suitable for their welfare, in our Residential Schools.

In view of the foregoing I cannot recommend that Jessie be re-admitted to a Residential School.

Yours very truly,

H. Ellis, Esq.,
Principal,
C.of E. Residential School,
Onion Lake, Sask.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 115-1-10, dated the 15th inst., pertaining to a request to have Jessie Burns of the Fort a la Corne North Day School transferred to the Onion Lake Residential School.

Agency records show that this girl was admitted to this Residential School at the age of 4 years and 4 months in Oct. 1932, and was discharged therefrom in 1934 on account of having been absent for a year owing to illness; also that she attended the Indian Day School on her Reserve from January 1935 until the end of June 1937.

On receipt of application dated Oct. 4th, and received on Oct. 12th from the Rev. H.E. Ellis, Principal of the Residential School, to have this girl re-admitted to his School, I made enquiries as to why she was taken from the Day School without first consulting this office. I was informed that Mr. Ellis had this girl taken from her home on the Reserve on Sept. 2nd last, without even advising Mr. E.S. Jones, the Reserve Inspector, who lives near one of the Reserves.

While on the Namu Smith's Reserve on Oct. 26th, I interviewed Angus Burns, father of Jessie, and asked him why Jessie had been sent back to the Residential School. He advised me that this girl should be home attending the Day School as he was able to look after her.

I also made enquiries from Mr. Jones, Farm Instructor. He advised me that this girl had a fair home on the Reserve and that her parents were able to properly provide for her; also that her home was within easy reach of the Day School.

On Nov. 2nd I wrote the Rev. Mr. Ellis to the effect that in view of the circumstances pertaining to this case I could not recommend that Jessie be re-admitted to the Residential School.

On receipt of Inspector T. Robertson's letter of Nov. 15th quoting Departmental letter #115-1-10, dated Nov. 8th last, I advised the Rev. Ellis as to the Department's wishes in this matter. He replied to my letter on Dec. 6th, which reads, in part, as follows:

"Would you kindly ask the Department and recommend that they reconsider the decision recently made."

For your information, I wish to state that I am asking the Secretary of the Indian Eskimo School Commission to also take the matter up personally with the Department at Ottawa."

On Dec. 11th I advised Mr. Ellis that as no further reason had been submitted as to why this girl should be taken away from her home and Day School on her Reserve I could not grant his request.

I feel that if the Principals of the Residential Schools are permitted to come onto Indian Reserves and take children from good homes and Day Schools, as has been done in this case, it will eventually result in having to close our Day Schools. I also feel that a Principal has no right to go onto an Indian Reserve and take children into Residential Schools without first obtaining permission from the Department.

Trusting that the Department will concur with the action I have taken in this matter.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of the 24th inst., No. 115-1-10, dealing with the case of Jessie Burns, and beg to state that I have this day written to the Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of our Society's School at Onion Lake, asking him to have this girl returned to her home at his earliest convenience, and to notify the Indian Agent concerned of the date of her return.

As Onion Lake is approximately 40 miles from the railway there is a possibility that weather and road conditions may make it impossible for her to be sent home immediately, but I have no doubt my instructions will be carried out without any avoidable delay.

I am reminding Mr. Ellis of standing instructions issued to the principals of all our Society's Schools some time ago to maintain at all times the closest possible harmony with your Department's local representatives and to give them the fullest possible cooperation.

By way of explanation of Mr. Ellis' action in taking Jessie Burns back to his School, I may say that he was adhering to a Departmental ruling given some years ago, and carefully observed by us ever since, that
children who have been admitted to one School should not be transferred to another without being officially discharged after having completed their education. As Jessie had not been officially discharged, Mr. Ellis felt that he was justified in having her returned to his School after recovering from her illness, as her name was still on the register.

I am, however, at a loss to know why he did not consult your representative on the Reserve at the time, and I have asked him for an explanation. While dealing with this subject, I may say that some years ago our Society and the Diocese of Saskatchewan, where a number of Day Schools are maintained, came to an understanding that children who had been in the Indian Day Schools until they reached eleven years of age, should then be transferred to the Residential Schools.

While your predecessor, the late Mr. Ferrier, thought this a very helpful arrangement on the part of Church authorities, he felt that it would not be prudent, at any rate at that time, for his Department to issue a standing order making this arrangement applicable throughout the Dominion.

Speaking for myself personally, as well as for our Commission, I would like to say that I still consider the arrangement possesses very real benefits for all the Indian children. It would leave them while still very young, under the immediate care and tutelage of their parents. Then the transfer to the Residential Schools would help to widen their vision and establish contacts with children from other parts which may lead to life-long friendships, and help to prevent the in-breeding process, which has proved so disastrous amongst these, as well as other peoples.

With very good wishes for the incoming year,

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Enclosed are application for admission forms covering ten pupils who have apparently been admitted to the St. Alban's Indian Residential School at Prince Albert. With the exception of one case the children to whom the applications refer were admitted to the School without my knowledge. I did not consent to the one case I had knowledge of.

There are 130 pupils in residence at the St. Alban's School at the present time including the ten children now referred to. The quota I understand is 100 or 105 pupils. It may be argued that home conditions in some cases concerning the children whose applications are now being forwarded may not be satisfactory. On the other hand there is the matter of overcrowding and fire hazard connected with this building.

I can not recommend the Admission of the pupils concerned. If the Department approves I will be pleased to complete the Application forms enclosed.

E. S. Jones,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 19, 1947.

Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Agent,
Leask, Saskatchewan.

I desire to refer to your letter of October 22nd, enclosing application form to cover children admitted to the St. Alban's Residential School.

It is noted that there is a much larger enrollment at that school than has been previously authorized. This situation is undoubtedly due in part at least, to the destruction of the Lac la Ronge Residential School which was also conducted under the auspices of the Church of England.

It has been decided to approve the temporary admission of these children to the St. Alban's School until such time as we can provide accommodation for them at some other residential school.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Fisher:

We have your letter of the 4th instant enclosing application for admission of children to the St. Alban's Residential School.

The Department is concerned with the very large number of children whom you have enrolled. The accommodation must be taxed to the utmost.

With regard to the application forms which you have forwarded, it is noted that Laura Mabel Constant, Irene Ruby Head, Hazel Alice Head and Mary Ann Burns are from the James Smiths reserve. In all these cases the parents are stated to be living and in addition there is a day school in operation on the reserve. Under these circumstances we would like to know why you have accepted these children in view of the extremely large enrollment that you have at the present time. This enrollment, as you know, is greatly in excess of your authorized pupilage.

Please let me hear further from you.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your Letter 115-1-10 (WT 1)

I have received your letter of November 29, 1947 commenting on the over-crowded condition of this school, and asking why I took in so many children.

The chief reason for my taking in some of these children was that it had come to my knowledge that a new school would be opened in Prince Albert as a temporary Lac la Ronge School, and that when this school was opened some of our children could be transferred to it. Unfortunately, and much to my personal disappointment, the Church did not at once accept the Department's offer of this school, and so thus the transfer could not be made.

Referring specially to the four children from the James Smith's Reserve, these were brought into school at the special request of the Rev. Canon Ahemakew who gave me the impression that these particular children's home condition was not particularly good, and that they were not attending school regularly in any case. I might add that Louise Constantine's mother is at present in the Prince Albert Sanatorium, hence she would be without her mother's care at home.

Sometime ago Inspector of Indian Agencies Ostrander was in to see me. He mentioned it was his intention to write to the Department regarding the over-crowded condition of this school. Mr. Jones was with him. It was agreed that it would be a pity to have to return children to their homes, and I suggested that it might be possible to use one of the Army Huts offered for school purposes as an annex to this school. Mr. Ostrander appeared to be in favour of this, and told me that if this were agreed to, he would be willing to recommend that we be paid grants for all the children enrolled.

The plan I have in mind would be to be to open up one building as dormitory for our boys. Then to bring them by truck to St. Alban's for meals and classroom work, and to return them to the annex each evening after supper. The annex would be placed in charge of a married couple. The distance between St. Alban's and the annex would be but one mile, and it should present no greater difficulty in getting the boys backwards and forwards to school than is experienced by day schools where bus service is provided. One of the buildings for school purposes could be fitted up within two weeks for the plan suggested. Of course, I put forward this idea merely as a temp-

orary measure, until such time as the other buildings can be adapted for use as a complete school unit.

May I say I do not wish it to be thought I am wishing to go over the heads of any local Departmental officials in bringing this before you, but rather to give greater emphasis as to the reason I took in such children. I would not wish to have to return any of the children in question to their homes, and I feel sure that there would be no difficulty in taking care of all of them until such time as the complete new set-up is ready if the annex suggestion were agreed to. I would ask that the idea be given careful consideration, and that I be notified of the Department's decision in the matter.

Dear Mr. Fisher:

We have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the overcrowded conditions in the St. Alban's Residential School. It is now the intention of both the Department and the M.S.C.C. to proceed with the temporary school in Prince Albert military camp. Arrangements for this are being completed as quickly as possible.

As soon as these buildings are formally taken over, there will be plenty of room to relieve the overcrowding in the St. Alban's School. In the meantime you should exercise every care.

Yours sincerely,

In forwarding my Quarterly Returns for the quarter ending December 31st, I would call your attention to the fact that #361 - Everett Bear, and his sister #364 Jean Myrtle Bear, were allowed to return home because their mother was ill. I am sorry to lose these children, as they were doing quite well in school. The father asked whether at some later date he could return them to school. Reference is made to letter 115-1-10 (E.1) of June 16, 1948 re: children admitted to St. Alban's Indian Residential School from the Sturgeon Lake Reserve.

Dr. McFadyen of the Prince Albert Health Unit advised that Mrs. Natowahow, an ex-patient of the Prince Albert Sanitorium was physically unable to look after her children; consequently, Joseph, Stella and Beatrice Natowahow were admitted to St. Alban's school.

Shirley Roberts and Margaret Rose Roberts were admitted on account of the death of their mother. Their father is of the nomadic type and spends the greater part of his time wandering from one reserve to the other.

In the case of Harvey and Carol Kingfisher, these children were pupils of the Sturgeon Lake Day School, but had to travel a distance of 7 miles to get to school.

In the case of Sophie Ross and Dorothy Catherine Bird, the home conditions under which these children lived were such that it was considered advisable to remove them to the Residential School.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Runaway Children-All Saints Indian Residential School, Prince Albert, Sask.

As arranged during our discussion in your office this morning I send you herewith a copy of a letter, dated 21st October, 1948, from the Rev. G.W. Fisher regarding the difficulties he is experiencing in the matter of children running away from All Saints School, Prince Albert.

It is of interest to note that the Principal feels that discharge of any of the culprits will aggravate the present situation.

I have informed Rev. G.W. Fisher that you are asking your local Agent to cooperate with him and the R.C.M.P. in an effort to put a stop to this practice of children running away from the School.

In a sense there is a connection between this and the letter dealing with the unfinished condition of our buildings, and which is going forward with this.

I would first of all apologise for having allowed a great deal of my office work to get behind. But this has happened not because of neglect, but because I have had to be on the road a great deal trying to bring back runaway boys.

Ever since the school opened children have been continually running away from school, and many precious hours have been spent, and much gasoline used in trying to get them back. Many fruitless trips have been made. Since September 5th, my car has travelled 2400 miles, two thirds of which at least, were in connection with trying to get children back to school. I am really in despair. Many of these runaways have been off four and five times. It is hard to know just what to do. I really feel like turning some of them out of school altogether, but this is probably what many of them would like me to do, and others might do the same in order to get out also.

My chief regret is that the Quarterly Returns are not yet completed, but I am hoping they will be ready to forward next week. Petty Cash Statements for August and September will also be sent as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) G.W. Fisher

Principal.

December 8th, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enclosed herewith please find Application for Admission into St.Albans Indian Residential School located at Prince Albert, Sask covering the following Indian children from the James Smith Band No. 100.

McLeod, Maurice Arthur, Age 8 years No. 176,
McLeod, Lloyd Joseph Norman, " 15 " No. 89,
Head, Roderick, " 10 " No. 136,
Head, Phillip Norman, " 14 " No. 136,
Moostocs, Edward Clifford, " 10 " No. 133,

The above named Indian children were admitted on September 1st, 1948 and discharged November 1st, 1948, and were in attendance for a period of two months.

The reason for this action was due to arrangements being made with the parents to enter into a fur conservation area in the Pasquia Game Preserve at or near Hudson Bay Junction Saskatchewan and in view of the fact that educational facilities would not be available to their children it was decided to have them placed in the above named Indian School. When the parents were advised to come into this area it was found that only four families could be accommodated again with the results that due to overcrowding in the St.Albans School arrangements were made with the parents to remove their children to their homes on their reservation and have the children attend at Day Schools on their reservation.

The above named children were therefore only in attendance for a two month period at St.Albans Indian School and I recommend that their admission be approved for that period only and the usual grant paid to the St.Albans Indian Residential School covering the months of September and October, 1948, on behalf of the children above mentioned.

M. J. McLeod,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
